>>56435500
Whenever you take a look at the state of the German military, you have to understand the circumstances they exist in.

Directly after the second world war the cold war stepped in and suddenly the German military of either side was becoming important again because they would be the first line of defense. Both sides advertised the benefits and necessity of having a functional military.

Then somewhere towards the end of the cold war people became disillusioned about our prospects in case such war would actually break out in every single scenario that would include nuking the fuck out of Germany, so pacifist movements started appearing. Those movements can be attributed to play a major role in the civil resistance against the occupying forces of either side.

Eventually the iron curtain came down and the military was merged. Now all the civilians were aware of the fact that a certain part of the military had been practicing to literally nuke the opposite part of the population which didn't exactly make their popularity skyrocket. Pacifist movements continued to gain traction and since no enemy was visible, the reputation of the military further degraded. At this point it was seen as a completely pointless money sink, and everyone who was in it as some sort of fuckhead. Budget cuts were on the menu as well.

Public approval was low, and so became the morale by the military. Public figures openly mocked the pointlessness of the military service and nobody ever intervened. And so people stopped caring about their jobs because nobody in the public did either. Everyone in the military was doing the bare minimum because it didn't really matter if you did something or didn't. Also the budget was way too high, so let's cut it.

And if you stay in this alcoholic limbo for about 30 years you end up where we are right now.

posts.com:
I was very confused why they're upgrading an already modern IFV and I ended up doing about 10 minutes of extensive research and now I'm even more confused.
The Puma has been shit from the start and is planned to replace the Marder only by 2030. Even though we already have 350 Pumas. Even though we already ordered over 200 more for some reason.
The Bundeswehr knows the Puma is flawed. In 2020 the Bundeswehr decided that the Puma has too many defects as it is right now to be part of NATOs Very High Readiness Joint Task Force. Luckily they already tasked KMV and Rheinmetall Landsysteme (who build the Puma in a joint venture) and Rheinmetall Electronics with figuring out how to integrate Rheinmetalls Electronics new fancy IdZ concept into the Puma in 2019. IdZ stands for infantry grunt of the future or whatever and is mostly about fancy communication systems as far as I understand it.
So they come up with the Puma IdZ-ES/Puma System Panzergrenadier which has better optics, better armor and most importantly a bunch of new comms equipment. The Bundeswehr ends up buying the upgrade for 41 of their Pumas in 2021 with the goal of integrating them into the VJTF in 2023.

So they took an already flawed base product, rushed some upgrades, rushed the approval, and ended up with a tank that falls apart after moderate usage. Who could have thought.

posts.name: Resident Wumbologist

>>56429380
The primary advantage of a shotgun is that it has a ton of instant energy transfer potential per trigger pull. It doesn't necessarily penetrate body armor, but if it's soft armor that guy is going to be on the floor coughing up blood with a broken ribcage anyway. If you're expecting guests with solid plates then you probably have bigger problems.

Besides that
>Shotguns that are good enough can be very cheap. Mav 88 for example.
>Legal to own in many jurisdictions with restrictive laws.
>Better jury optics in states without effective or respected castle doctrine laws.
>Effective against large dangerous animals, which can be a bigger problem than humans in many places.
>Fairly easy learning curve, so long as you can deal with the recoil.
>#4 buckshot is great for minimizing over-penetration, #00 is good enough to not take out your neighbors.

Mind you, I still think a throwaway budget AR-15 with 30rds of frangible ammunition is better but a $200 Maverick 88 with a light and 5+1rds of #4 Buck is more than adequate for the vast majority of HD situations.
If you have an AR or something like it use that by all means, but every collection should have a shotgun since there's so much that they bring to the table and they're so cheap that there isn't much reason not to have at least one.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Shotguns are not close range weapons, despite what COD tells you.
They are designed to get hits at 100 yards or more, the spread makes smaller targets (birds) easier to hit and the number of pellets helps where there might be obstructions (trees) in the line of fire.

At close range the overall barrel length, rate of fire and magazine capacity make them unsuitable.
While they will absolutely drop someone, the issue isn't ballistic but logistic.

Statistics are frequently used to misrepresent the effectiveness of shotguns, which takes several common forms.
>focus on ballistic performance
Eg. How many shots it takes to end an engagement. By this standard a 4 bore shotgun is the best weapon after a howitzer.
>defining sets so to discount readiness
Basically the pistol owner has access to their weapon, the shotgun owner is caught empty handed, the statistics group the shotgun owner with "unarmed" victims.
>demographic factors
Shotguns are owned by men, and white men, and people who actually use their guns.
Really you've just measured who's doing the shooting, given an SBR or pistol that same demographic would perform.

Really you want a pistol, because the biggest factor is whether you are carrying your weapon when you need it. Second and closely related is how quickly you can access your weapon.
Third is the willingness of the owner to shoot first.
Fourth is shot placement
Only then does ballistic performance come into play.

Put it this way, if you've got a .38 in your pocket and a shotgun beside the door, when a window breaks would you rather hold point with the pistol or run for the shotgun?
A .38 snubby is not a good choice, but even this beats the shotgun simply because it's in your hand faster.

Tangent, but related: CRT TVs put out a small amount of radiation; some time in the 40s or 50s IIRC some cheap TVs were putting out a little too much so the government (US) ended up regulating how much radiation they can put out and started requiring companies to just make the front of the picture tubes out of leaded glass. It blocks at least some of the radiation. And no, you're not getting eye or brain cancer from a CRT; even at sitting-at-desk distances, it gives roughly the same radiation as the sun itself. I think sapphire lenses block out some radiation. I know our chromatography machine has doped sapphire glass lenses for when we throw radioactive stuff in it. Expensive as fuck though, and some kinds of radiation can apparantly cause the lens to be "polluted" by causing lens material to turn into isotopes that decay into contaminants. Cool about CRT's, didn't know that. I know leaded glass has a lot of neat properties, great optics too, shame it got turned into a health-care and dropped out of favour as drinking glass material. It's only really an issue if you store high proof alcohol long-term in decanters. Drinking glasses emptied in 1 sitting leech next to no lead into the contents.

Just offhandedly a /k/ subject topic; do anyone know if gun optics are from any particular type of glass? I'm not sure what kind is used for lenses in general, much less scopes or holosights.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56437111
Depends on the duty station, your unit, MOS, and rank
At certain places you move out at E1, some you move out at E4 with a waiver, many you start getting shoved off at NCO (E5), some places you're only getting off at E7 (korea). E6 is the by regulation guaranteed separate housing.

AIT you will sleep in the same bedroom as another guy like college almost guaranteed. Almost all barracks have/are moving to separate bedrooms shared kitchens. Most branches are doing this (besides the Marines, they won't do this for like 40 years).
Some places are at 100% capacity and you'll move out instantly because they have no barracks space at all. It's a total lottery.
35N -> cyber -> Meade is a very good deal, by the time you make it there from training you'll be an E4 and be able to apply for an ETP to move out immediately and never really live barracks life if its not for you. Some people prefer it greatly, living right next to PT locations and the commissary and all your homies.
Some places have four dudes to a college dorm room because shit's rough and they got no space. Total lottery like many things in the Army/DoD/Government in general.

>>56396143
that IFAK price is kinda optimistic nowadays. a real poorfag IFAK that will perform close to what is in this pic would be:
>2x cravat, $4, works as a TQ but not as effective as a commercial tourniquet
>4x kurlex gauze rolls, $5-10 (combat gauze is unnecessary, 75th ranger btn. did a study on this and no noticeable difference between hemostatic and regular gauze was found)
>2x ace wraps $3-7 iirc
>plastic baggie or two + some duct tape $1, works as a chest seal and is what 90% of EMTs use even in the states (throw a gauze pad into the baggie for wiping blood and dirt off the injury before applying the plastic bag - adds $2)
>medical shears $5-15, depending on brand
>roll of medical tape for smaller cuts etc
--------additional investement--------
2x CAT7 tourniquet. these are super important but go for $30+ a pop nowadays so not too poorfag friendly. you can snag two for $50 sometimes.
>compressed gauze from NAR or H&H (less bulk than kurlex rolls, but essentially the same thing - about $5 a pop)

shit like NPAs and decomp needles are a meme and never utilized by anyone in real life. TCCC doesnt even teach NPA application anymore, they favor the recovery position. decomps are often applied incorrectly even by paramedics and will kill people if done wrong + they very, very rarely make a difference.

>>56402687
Advice? Make sure it's fitted right so it doesn't rub. Plan for how you'll manage water, my rig has two standard canteens and space for two water bladders if needed. Generally, manage straps, zippers and dangling crap.
Probably the biggest issue is carrying sleeping gear. LBE can hold something like a hammock, tarp and polyethylene easily but tents and sleeping bags are not as easy. It depends on where and how you are sleeping.
My understanding is that in most long range patrol, which hunting in LBE is closest to, soldiers used poncho + light sleeping bag at most for sleeping, maybe in Vietnam carry a half bivouac. Depends on how dirty you want to get.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Speaking of comms anyone into GMRS radio?
The lioscense is good for 10 years, doesn't require a test and your immediate family can legally transmit over GMRS using your call sign.
I know some people think they're going to make contact with strangers on HAM radio when the SHTF and save the day but the reality is you need to communicate with your people and GMRS is simple. Chances are you're the only one in your family that's into this shit and you can hand anyone a GMRS radio and show them how to use it in 5 minutes.
They can also communicate with shitty FRS "walkie talkies" on the lower channels if that's all your friend's/family have but you should buy two radios minimum because us poorfags are probably going to have to provide comms for our poorfag family/friends.
The UV-5G can be used as a scanner, listen to HAM bands, get NOAA weather alerts, FM commercial radio, communicate with GMRS repeaters and it looks exactly like a UV-5R for that maximum operator LARP look and takes UV-5R accessories.
>UV-5G
>External speaker mic with audio jack output
>Noise canceling earpro with audio input
Poor fags comms setup.
Alternatively you can "jail break" a UV-5R HAM radio to illegally transmit on GMRS so you can communicate with "walkie talkies".

posts.com:
It’s an interesting question to think about what’s the most optimal strategy on average. Obviously running away is always the best one if you can just jump out of the window, but assuming that there’s no exit close by, you have no weapons, and the route out is long, it becomes a tougher call.

In individual sense, there’s probably nothing worse than trying to hide in an office and having an active shooter come in and bust you there, but then again, most active shooters aren’t exactly the most efficient and systematic killers, and usually tend up shooting people randomly in corridors, couple of random rooms, or around their possible main target if they have one. Maybe it is adrenaline making them hyperfocused on what’s in their immediate view, but that kind of means that unless you happen upon them, previous IRL experience shows that they’re unlikely to dig you out, and assuming an office corridor with dozens of rooms, hiding seems like a pretty good option for your average panicking civilian. You die if the shooter enters your room, true, but rushing out to corridor mskes the likelihood of meeting the shooter in the first plage much bigger unless you can be sure that they’re further away.

Not defending any dumbfuck ”always hide even if you have exit nearby” instructions, but assuming a long exit route and uncertainty about the shooter’s location, hiding doesn’t seem like thay bad of an option.

posts.com:
Here's my take:

Of 100 active shooter callous only 2 will be "mass shootings".
20 will be hoaxes, 40 will be sub critical incidents 30 will be general crime.
The remaining ten are critical incidents, a real mass shooting.
3 will end spontaneously with the public taking out the shooter, it might be unclear whether a mass shooting was or wasn't going to unfold but in this 3% we count someone who intended to carry out a mass shooting.
3 incidents will be a wipe out with the shooter having killed everyone before there's a police response, the shooter picked a very soft target.
3 will end in a standoff where the shooting has halted but victims are still present.
1 the shooter has left the scene

Fill these values in with real statistics if you like but that's about my read of it.

Thus the response is generally hardening targets. Why? Because that's effective against sub critical threats and doesn't lead to an escalation in hoax calls.
The school gets better locks and internally sections the building.
If the school got a security guard (critical response) you'd have an escalation in sub critical threats (Someone seen outside with a gun, robbery nearby, aggressive parent) which are 80 times more likely.
If you took a systematic response (limiting class sizes, positioning schools outside metro areas, banning firearms) you wouldn't actually get any protection from a critical incident.

That's the hard part of security, balancing resources and priorities

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
My building for example got a massive security overhaul because the government decided we were a soft target.

We were getting one sub critical incident every week, there were targeted demographics present, we had no real security plan. Imagine a tax department office where customers regularly threatened us, got pushy in the front desk or made hoax calls.

There were several key key changes
A. Our fire exits were assessed for human threats, turns out someone could have parked a car blocking one of our fire escapes because it led into the carpark and we wouldn't have known unless someone actually tried to use the fire escape.
The second fire escape was found to be unsuitable because an external fire could have blocked it.
Basically someone could have parked against the first door, walked around with a jerry can and torched the second door and within 30 seconds entered the front door. Bad situation.

So bollards were put up around the first door to stop anyone parking there, it wasn't a parking space but people routinely parked there anyway.
The second door was fire proofed with an angled cement section to repel flammable liquid and an external sprinkler was installed.

B. Ability for a shooter to trap people on any section or floor was reduced.
Internal security doors were installed, extra doors were put in between rooms, the stairwell was modified so someone standing in the first stairwell couldn't shoot at the second one.

C. External security cameras were now able to be monitored by reception staff to better deal with sub critical threats, as these were in public the privacy consideration was considerably less serious, nobody wanted karen to spy on them smoking in the carpark but reception needed that visibility to identify someone who had attempted entry from one side of the building and then went around. That person would be drunk or lost 99% of the time but this let reception lock the front door

I think one of my favorites for the history of it and how obscure it is, is the crest for the HQ for the German-Netherlands Battalion
It has the “peace rider”, who rode between the two towns during the signing of the Treaty of Westphalia, in front of the specific building that it was signed in
The HQ is located in Münster which is one of those two cities
It’s cool to me to have a historical figure and location from the 1600s on a modern unit crest, that ended the Thirty Years War and made country borders what they are today

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/339th_Infantry_Regiment_(United_States)
>The polar bear on its blue background is copied from the unofficial shoulder patch of the North Russian Expeditionary Force, of which this Regiment was a part during the years 1918-1919. The Regiment, organized in 1917, was made up to a large extent of men from Detroit, and was known locally as "Detroit's Own". The canton bears a part of the coat of arms of Cadillac, the founder of Detroit, and is symbolic of the origin of the Regiment and of its 1924 allocation. The motto is pronounced as though spelled in English "shtyk reshayet" (Russian pronunciation: [ˈʂtɨk rʲJˈʂajJt]). Literally translated it is "The bayonet settles it", freely translated it may be rendered "We Finish With The Bayonet".

>>56430594
Heraldically, the image on the left and the image on the right are 100% absolutely identical. It has a field of blue (11th-century French not making a distinction between hexadecimal color codes) and a silver lion standing on its hind legs.
Why is that specified? Because someone or something else might have a coat of arms with a silver lion on a blue field that's standing on all fours. But there's no distinction made between lions with or without their dick and balls hanging out, so depicting lion-junk is an artistic choice.
The coat of arms isn't the image itself. It's the written description of the image.

The motif is six coins representing the fare paid to the ferryman of the river to the afterlife, which allegedly symbolizes the readiness of the Sanada clan to put their life on the line to achieve victory.
Surprisingly, they actually lived up to what their emblem represents. The first patriarch of the clan lost everything in war, threw his lot in with Takeda Shingen when Shingen was still just a fairly minor warlord, and then won everything he had lost back on the battlefield as one of Shingen's generals. The second patriarch lost everything when the Takeda clan was effectively destroyed at Nagashino and then won everything back by successfully playing all of the major warlords against each other, to his own benefit. The third patriarch was Sanada Yukimura, who almost killed Tokugawa Ieyasu and who had made an agreement with his brother that they would fight on opposite sides in the last stages of the civil war. This was so that no matter which side won in the end, their clan would survive and prosper--which it did. The Sanada clan is still around today. One of Yukimura's descendants is a professional baseball player: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hiroki_Sanada

posts.com:
At the time 5.56 was an improvement over 30.06 because being able to shoot through a tree a guy and another tree with a standard infantry rifle was overkill. The average engagement distance was too short to warrant the extra range from a full sized rifle cartridge and carrying the ammo was a pain since it was so heavy. So they switched to 5.56 which is lighter and easier to carry. Now with more armies handing out armor as standard issue and engagement ranges being much longer due to easily accessible advanced optics its more important to have a stronger round with increased range. Hence they pushed for 6.8.

And before a bunch of autists cry about how 6.8 cant defeat armor or some other tinfoil hat MUGH 5.56 IS BETTUR garbage and jerk off about how nothing will ever be as good as 5.56 nobody that says they know or claims to know how good it is against armor has actually fired the actual military spec ammo. Nobody actually knows how good it is against armor but there is one indisputable fact and that is it WILL be better against it than 5.56 while having increased range which are the two reasons it was pushed for adoption in the first place.

Basically in a time when nobody had any armor full power cartridges were stupid so they scaled back so people could carry more and now that its likely to see more armor on the battlefield higher power cartridges are going to make a comeback.

>>56428189
Ammo usage in a military sense is very different compared to a civilian's use of ammo. Practical civilian usage usually revolves around accuracy, whether that be on the range plinking paper or tin cans, hunting, or wildcat autism and very little full auto blasting. In warfare the true killers are explosives from tanks/artillery, air support, grenades, and so on while bullets are more used for suppressing. Suppress, maneuver. Suppress, maneuver. Suppress, maneuver. Suppression doesn't always mean massed automatic fire from dedicated machine guns, suppression through accuracy is a thing.
Eventually the enemy will run away or you'll get fire support.
If not then you'll maneuver into a good position for your DMRs/grenades/rockets/whatever heavier weapons you've got in the squad to reliably engage. You don't want to go crazy with those as you've only got a limited amount of ammo for them.
Or you'll eventually maneuver into such a superior position that it won't matter what exact cartridge you're firing.
So you need a cartridge that is lightweight so a squad can carry a lot but still have a usable range to suppress, accuracy to either suppress the enemy at range if not hit and kill them outright, and ability to reliably kill at shorter ranges. That is why the .223 was adopted into the 5.56 and the 7.62*51 was relegated to more specialized weapons.
I can't answer why is the military moving to the spicy 6.8 instead of back to the 7.62 NATO as I haven't done enough reading on that to answer with any kind of confidence but you could probably answer most military questions with "someone gave a five star a five star dick sucking".

>>56428189
>so why did wthe US start using 556 and not go back to 7.62 or what ever the fuck it is
5.56 was adopted in the midst of the Vietnam war, it allowed soldiers to carry more ammo which would end up being used against targets with no ballistic protection at close to medium ranges.
It's design was one created from the lessons learned from the Korean war and the US using M14s/M1s as their main combat rifle (chambered in .308 (NATO 7.62x51) and .30-06 (NATO "I don't care what you're standing behind"x"Oh fuck I just had a runaway malfunction on my M1 and my shoulder doesn't exist anymore" respectively).
It has a much lighter kick, can be loaded into a lighter rifle, and does the job more than well enough unless your target has some serious ballistic protection, which makes it the single most ideal round for the US to have used from Vietnam to now.
Intermediate cartridges like 5.56 have more or less become the standard for those reasons, even Russian 7.62x39 is comparable in terms of overall cartridge size to 5.56, and even then, they ended up moving towards 5.45 to more closely mimic the projectile size of 5.56.
That being taken into account, NATO 7.62 (.308) is a far larger round that was completely excessive for the wars the US was fighting over the last several decades.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I have a lot of recurrent dreams that I cycle through, but one nightmare among them is a group of criminals who stalk and hunt my family. They aren’t typical gangbangers, but rather are white middle-aged psychopaths (with a cold woman as a leader) — think like Home Alone franchise villains but on steroids. They always have the most sinister expressions on their faces too: We go from town to town evading them, but they always find us eventually. The only difference is that instead of setting McCallister booby traps, I go straight to rifles and shotguns with the intent to kill. Sometimes I successfully defend my neighborhood / dwelling against them, other times the dream ends before I am killed, and the other outcomes vary. My tactics are almost always stealth / ambush rather than head-on engagements, though. ,

What most creeps me out is their unexplainable, persistent campaign against me / us. It’s some Michael Myers shit. I imagine that the nightmare is a manifestation of my greatest fear in life — losing or not being able to protect my family against a threat.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Before I had experience with guns I used to have dreams all the fucking time as a teen where whenever I would use a gun I would be unable to pull the trigger or load it. Like the trigger would be completely stiff or the magazine would just dematerialize or be empty, etc. Now as an adult, even in my worst nightmares I'm always able to fire my gun. I'm able to reload a shotgun/rifle without dropping the shell and all my guns fire when I pull the trigger. Though, although the gun will fire in all of my dreams, in some nightmares the creature or person be unaffected by the shot and I'll get killed. I swear, I've had some of the worst fucking nightmares since I was a young child, as even as young as 5, I remember vividly having nightmares about these creatures I called "the flying men". They ended up looking pretty much exactly like the Ringwraiths in LotR, so you can imagine my surprise when I saw that movie on release at age 12 and nearly had a heart attack seeing those creatures for the first time, as they would always kill me in horrific ways, or kill my parents, or wear my parents skin and kill me. God I still remember the first dream I had when I blasted one in the fucking face with a shotgun after years of actually owning and practicing with one and thankfully I haven't dreamt of them since.

>when can we expect megacorporations to have their own armed wings?
Not unless there's a massive societal upheaval. Remember we're getting the bad parts of cyberpunk. Not the cool shit. Governments are REAL touchy about their monopoly on the use of force and would come down HARD on any billionaire trying to set up a private army more substantial than a bunch of rent-a-cops. IRL most private security is focused more on deterrence and prevention rather than stomping with their jackboots, the logical reason being 'it's all insured anyways', and the practical one is that most of the time it's fucking illegal and even when it isn't you'll still have to answer to a commission as to why your private police force gunned down a union demonstration. So, unless we get to the point where state power is either severely diminished or absent entirely (which creates it's own can of worms) we're not going to see cyberpunk private armies.

The punch line is they don't even need to. In our society private capital and state authority are part of the same goddamn power structure anyways. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
In my opinion, although the Grot was clearly very heavily inspired by the ACR (and structurally based on AR-18... like most guns), it looks better. In fact I think it's one of the best looking guns out there.

Not to mention the technical side of it. Here it is in the carbine variant, there's also the standard variant, sharpshooter variant (which will replace the Dragunov) and, last but not least, the bullpup variant (complete novelty, will be used by our tankers, drivers and paras) and it's ALL THE SAME GUN, the same main body, you just replace 3 large modules with 3 other large modules that you buy (e.g. "bull-pup conversion kit," "sharpshooter conversion kit" i.e. 7.62 conversion kit, and it's all designed so that it skirts around the stringent laws so you can buy the conversion kits themselves without any additional approval/certification).
The bullpup also has a great weight distribution, great trigger, isn't too heavy, can have a long or short barrel, is ambidextrous, there's pretty much no recoil, it's very accurate (and as accurate as the standard MSBS)... It's the best bullpup in Europe if not in the world.
The first version, before 2017, was the A0. The first mass production version, A1, was riddled with problems, such as the bolt carrier breaking. It's been fixed in the A2 version, and they're working on A3 now, when it's supposed to be a pitch perfect weapon.

MSBS will replace Beryl, Dragunov and additionally expand the capabilities of the rifle stock and will become the service weapon of the Polish Armed Forces completely by 2028. It was part of Projekt Tytan, the Polish super-soldier of the future, but it was bumped off of it so that it could progress faster on its own (the rest of the project is now catching up with it, with prototypes being made for every single component that makes up Projekt Tytan).

I think you massively underestimate armour, we use armour today, armour was used in ww2 and ww1, armour was used at the same time as black powder muskets. Elephants were used at the same time as black powder muskets.
Musket balls couldnt penetrate properly 'proofed' armour until the late 17th.c, whereupon armour which remained proofed had to become excessively thick. A musket ball fired from a flintlock, can generally penetrate, according to its calibre, the equivalent cm thickness in steel. For example a .75 brown bess musket could penetrate .75 of a cm in steel, or 7.5mm. Steel breastplates of around 6mm at the centre, which were somewhat angled, were often enough to stop musket balls at their strongest point at close range, or generally at longer range, but it was heavy and cumbersome. Modern cased ammunition is much higher velocity but isnt neccessarily better at penetrating armour unless it is armour piercing. m955 tungsten .556 AP can penetrate 12mm at 100 metres, allegedly. .556 ball is much worse, i cant find exactly how much worse, all i've found is 3mm at 600 metres. Either way the penetration falls off drastically at range, especially compared to a .303 or 7.62.
The main way that really big game is taken down, is not with a .556, its with an appropriate sized round, .375 is the legal minimum generally, and with a shot to the heart or a shot to the brain, and this sometimes doesnt work.
If that troll has armour like in the pic, that covers its head and heart, if the armour is as thick as it looks in that image, i'd say at least 2cm, then basically the only way you'll be able to damage the troll enough to stop it killing you is by shooting its face, which it could probably shield with one of its arms. Or maybe if you manage to hit its feet/legs enough, but its got incredibly thick and tough hide which might even stop ball ammo at range, incredibly thick and tough bones, and its huge. So many of these shots are likely to be flesh wounds.

>>56436807
Medieval plate for a human sized enemy yes, as in munitions grade steel, about 2mm thick, from about the 15th/16th.c. Going right through, it'll actually make the wound worse due to spalling.
As an aside; older rifle ball rounds might actually bounce off of high quality medieval plate at extreme angles and ranges, as in an impact heading almost tangential to the curve of a cuirass or helmet or other thicker piece of armour, although it would be a very unlucky or poor shot.

About 6-10mm of steel, as a flat plate, is enough to stop standard rifle rounds. Early modern plate depending on the impact angle, calibre, gun, and range, could therefore potentially stop a rifle round. This was generally 3-5mm thick, but could get up to 7mm, and actively used angling on the cuirass to increase its effectiveness. Very heavy though, and was only 7mm at the centre ridge of the cuirass, you could probably penetrate the limb armour, the helmet, and the extremities of the cuirass, but there would be areas and angles that the bullet would have great difficulty with, especially the thick+angled centre line of the cuirass. Irl in the 18th/19th.c, the proofed cuirass was resistant to muskets at most ranges from the front, but vulnerable to them at point blank range (excepting the centre ridge line) which is where cavalry often were, although musket ball's velocity dropped off a lot faster than any modern bullet. It is very unlikely to be able to stop AP rifle calibres even at range or poor impact angles though.

Mail and scale do nothing. Scale might stop a weaker pistol round at range if its thick enough, and has enough padding beneath.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>56436373
I could just (rightfully) dismiss you as noguns, but that would be the end of the discussion, so instead I'll indulge you. when comparing energies between muskets and modern intermediate cartridge rifles there is literally an order of magnitude of difference in penetrating power.

a .69 cal musketball shot out of a brown bess musket delivers about 600 ft lbs of energy (I am being generous for the sake of illustrating my point) which is about equivalent to a middling power magnum pistol like cheap .357 mag factory ammunition shot out of a 4" barrel

I chronoed my own ar15 with an 18" barrel shooting 55 gr bulk pmc ammo. It's basically cheapest, weakest ammo you can find for an ar15. the velocity was around 3150 fps which gives us an energy of 1200 fps.

the ar15 is about twice as powerful as a musket shot per shot, which doesn't really seem like that much more, but keep in mind that the cross-sectional area of the widest point of a .69 caliber musket ball is .38 in^2 and the cross-sectional area of a .22 caliber ball round is .038 in^2. so you are applying double the energy across an area that is 1/10th as large. Let's ignore the penetrating properties of the spitzer bullet design the 5.56 round uses and just focus on the amount of energy being dumped per square inch:

musket: 1578 ft lb / in^2
5.56: 31579 ft lb / in^2

so it's about 20 times the energy per area unit. and keep in mind the former was what swept steel plate armor off the battlefield, not the latter - it was modern metallurgy that brought back wearable hardened steel plates capable of actually stopping rifle bullets. You could convince me that the elves or the dwarves could magick up a metal that could stop an intermediate cartridge but the idea that the orcs used anything better than wrought iron armor and especially for their troll allies that they probably despised (like everything else) is questionable.

>>56437200
Yeah high medieval and early rennaisance plate armour was typically 1-3mm but the thickness varied throughout the set, the thickest parts were sometimes 4mm, but most of it was 2-3.5 mm ish on the cuirass and 1-2mm on the limbs, and that was sufficient to stop the weapons of the time. Matchlock arquebuses become popular during the Italian Wars, so plate starts becoming thicker to deal with them, although its still resistant. Late 16th.c onwards its much thicker, 3-5mm generally throughout the cuirass. Then proof cuirasses appear, which are heavier and feature a pinched peascod, these tend to be 5-7mm in the centre of the cuirass, and 3.5-4mm around the arm holes and the edges. Theyre completely shot proof until the late 17th.c, and remain shot resistant even afterwards. Now obviously this old steel isnt really comparable with modern steel, but point is that it was thick enough to stop firearms, and given the right angle, even crap steel armour can be of sufficient thickness to stop a rifle bullet. They'd be throwing 20mm armour plates on trolls because trolls are huge and dont care so much about the weight, they take a lot of impacts/hits and the armour wont be regularly maintained, and its hard to make armour that size so thin. Like, look at the thickness of the armour on OP's troll, compare the visible thickness of the arm armour with the gondorian's hand, its 3 fingers thick, 2cm is extremely conservative, it could easily be 5 cm, which is somewhat ridiculous but thats what it looks like. I'm just going off of what i'm shown.

>>56437241
I shoot shotguns.
I'm just telling you how musket balls performed vs armour, and that armour was resistant to musket balls. Armour did actually remain resistant to musket balls, but it became increasingly heavier and more expensive, and less of it was resistant at closer ranges. Modern metallurgy made it more effective versus modern bullets, but modern steel plates are essentially still following the shot proof cuirasses in being extremely thick, but limiting effective coverage to the centre of the chest. Modern bullets are more effective at armour penetration than muskets certainly, but steel quality improves a lot from the 15th.c onwards, for high quality armour you get high carbon and well tempered +hot quenched steels, which are easily equivalent to modern steels like EN C35-C75. There is absolutely not a big difference between modern mild and medium carbon steels and the steels of decent quality armour, including the ones which dealt with muskets. Yeah munition armour may often be much lower quality, but a lot of it was fairly decent, at least according to the figures given in "Knights and the blast furnace". Modern steels use manganese, which prevents impurities and so increases tensile strength, but high quality medieval steel can still match modern medium or mild steel. Its just a big difference in consistency and expense.
Obviously none of these steels are equivalent to actual modern ballistic steels, which are often 3/4 inch thick and expected to stop AP rounds, .but 556 ball cant go through 3/4 inch of even mild steel anyways.
I'm too tired to work out the maths for the kj/m2 to penetrate 7mm of 340-400 vickers plate hardness steel, angled at 20 degrees. I'm not sure exactly how well .556 ball performs vs angles, or exactly how many mm of medium carbon steel it can pen at 100 metres, or the drop off in penetration over distance.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>56425738
>I was talking to a range instructor that said people build AR's all the time and are totally clueless about SBR laws. Apparently people just have them all over and don't realize it's a felony
Yep, that's an absolute fact. If you put a modular firearm, a million clueless fucks are gonna go straight out and slap a short upper on a stocked lower, disregarding any NFA warnings you put in the box, made them click through to buy it, etc..

>nobody with a VFG on an AR pistol has ever been charged
Actually at least one person has been charged with that (although w/r/t a normal pistol, not an AR pistol), and ATF lost in court.
The statutory definition of "pistol" uses the word "originally", and the judge ruled that adding accessories to a preexisting rail does nothing to change whether the gun was _originally_ designed to be fired with one hand.
ATF tries to get around this by asserting that slapping a VFG onto a rail is actually making a whole new firearm, and this new firearm is "originally" two-handed and thus an AOW rather than a pistol. Of course, that interpretation is bullshit (surplusage canon).

Well, they actually make decent amount on library guns, provided the employee making the purchases are retarded. I didn't work the library, but I have a basic understanding. My numbers aren't 100%, but I would think close enough.
They generally will offer the customer 40%-50% of blue book value on the spot and then sell at or slightly above blue book. Anything over like 1500 I believe has to be approved by a district manager of some sort. They'll sometimes give a bonus for estate sales or anything more than like 5 guns. Accessories generally don't mean shit unless it's rare.
The location I was at was pretty busy, since it primarily served 2 states (Oregon and Washington). You'd get at least a dozen people coming in to sell their guns for massive loss for a quick buck and most unique guns we'd turn around for easy profit within a week. Anything that doesn't sell in 45 days employees could by at half way between acquisition price and asking price.
I miss the good old days. I've bought probably 20 guns through the gun library, all at some sort of discount. I think the best deals I got were a PS90 for 800 bucks and a finnish capture SVT-40 for 450.
Sometime tried to sell us a colibri. Distinct manager would only approve 3k. An employee personally offered the guy 5K cash on the spot. The library manager told the guy to not be retarded and go to an auction house instead. This was the one time we broke the rule and allowed live ammo in the library.

Russians committed 200k soldiers to the original push then began backfilling them from other theatres for a total force of ~400k-500k over the last year and are bringing in 500k new conscripts by Feb\March of 2023. Most places are reporting 30k-50k kia which means 90-150k casualties.

Ukrainains started off with something like 150k active and 600-800k reserves not including foreign volunteers and new conscripts, so it wouldn't be out of this world to have 50k-100k kia but it's probably closer to around 60-70k kia so not unbelievable they'd have 180k-210k casualties.

There comes a point where your losses break unit cohesion (men keep seeing replacements as their buddies die off and don't want to get to know them or send them out to be fodder, or new units comprised mostly of replacements are created) and further losses exponentially deplete combat effectiveness (you send units back out at 80, 70, 50% strength and they end up way, way outnumbered). The fact we're seeing 30-40% of the total committed troops being casualties is not crazy numbers. The Ukies are basically trading personell for equipment at around a 1.5:1 ratio which for the Russians is unsustainable (that will collapse their demographics) ergo the huge overwhelming inbound push.

The issue now for Ukranians is the war has fully, for everyone in the country, progressed to an extermination campaign as has happened so many times in the past which means HATO is going to get more involved and the Ukies are putting new targets, like Russian interior energy lines, on the table. Also if you don't have transmission infrastructure, might as well shut down nuke plants, and if you've got suicidal men with no future willing to strap radioactive material onto bombs or build missiles that can hit Russian cities....

War is hell kids.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>56405099
>>56405161
That's a Model 1891 infantry rifle, not a M91 Dragoon. Tula Arsenal didn't begin making Dragoon rifles until 1924; prior to that they only made infantry rifles. Given the date it might have been left in Finland after the Finnish Civil War ended, bought by Finland on the surplus market from other European countries in the 1920s-'30s, or captured from Russia during WW2. The [SA] marking wasn't adopted by Finland until 1942. $300 is a good deal if the bolt serial is matching; the Finns generally didn't care about keeping any of the other serialized parts matching to the rifle, but the bolt was important. It would also be worth checking the underside of the receiver tang (the very rearmost-part of the receiver) to see if the manufacturer and date marked there match the one on the barrel. The Finns were re-building M91 rifles from salvaged parts before they began making their own components, so it's entirely possible to find a Finnish rifle with a pre-1918 barrel from one maker but a receiver from another.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56424629
Shit, I actually didn’t know that. All of the 98k’s I’ve handled have it on the left-hand side like pic related, and lack the Wa number. Mea Culpa, anon.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56424747
>Shit, I actually didn’t know that. All of the 98k’s I’ve handled have it on the left-hand side like pic related, and lack the Wa number. Mea Culpa, anon.
What you posted is the Beschusstempel or firing proof which is found on the left side of receivers and barrels. The Waffenamt inspection stamp is found on either the right side of the receiver or the top from 1942 onwards depending on the manufacturer with a numerical code designating the inspection team present at the manufacturer from the HeeresWaffenAmt (HWA). Most small parts will bear the same stamp meaning that the part was inspected and met the manufacturing and dimensional spec it was designed to though this lessened as the war went on. Similar to the Eagle inspection marks found on US M1917 rifles during WWI.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56413529
If you can find primers, have a reloading kit (even the lee handloader) and surplus 7.62x54r, reloading .303 is easy since they both use the same diameter bullet (.310 to .312) and roughly the same powder weight (roughly same powder capacity and both cartridges made around the same era and using the same metallurgy).

Pull 7.62x54r bullets from case.
Dump powder.
Prime .303 case.
Dump powder in new case.
Seat bullet.

Heck some people have pulled 7.62x39mm and used the components for reduced recoil loads - just be aware 7.62x39mm is usually 122-125gr. instead of the usual 150-180gr. bullet for .303 (up to 200gr. round on earlier cartridges).

When /k/ was non-stop nugget worshiping, I went out and bought the best nugget available. Mine was a Tula hex receiver in great condition.
Eventually I gave it away as a gift. They aren't good rifles. The sight in is way off without the bayonet and the stocks are crude. That said, the bolt is a thing of beauty. I thought it then and thought it now. The simplistic nature of it's design and the way it pulls out of the gun, then exists on a basically flat plane is extremely elegant. The safety is elegant. The pieces are large and heavy but they fit together with this almost art deco vibe. It's like a real work of art.

Like the other anon said usually all the manuals I've seen specify to zero the rifle at 100m with the elevation turret set to 1 and windage turret set to 0. When you have zeroed the scope you need to slightly unscrew the two external screws on the top of the turret (not the central one) and being careful of not moving the top black portion of the turret, turn the body to 1 for elevation and 0for windage.
On a translation of a soviet svd manual it says to zero the rifle with elevation at 3 and windage at 0, my assumption is that this is more of a rough battle zero. I'll add that the additional chevrons for beyond 1000 meters are accurate only when the elevation turret is set to 10.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56431271
>>56430548
>On a translation of a soviet svd manual it says to zero the rifle with elevation at 3 and windage at 0

That is a bad translation / misunderstanding of the official zeroing procedure.
The "3" setting is used during zeroing at 100m, but it does NOT result in a 100m zero.
It's a bit complicated so let's look at the overall procedure according to the Soviet SVD manual:

>take the PSO-1 off the rifle
>set the irons to "3"
>target the center bottom edge of the zeroing target (20x30 cm black rectangle)
>the ideal point of impact is 16cm directly above the point of aim
>adjust irons until this is achieved (irons are zeroed)
>mount the PSO-1 on the rifle and set the elevation turret to "3"
>secure the rifle in a zeroing rest and aim the irons back at the center of the bottom edge of the target
>tape a small white rectangle over the point of aim afterwards
>look down the scope
>the top chevron should be aimed right at the white rectangle
>if it isn't, loosen the screws and move it there, then retighten them
>verify zero of the scope by shooting a test group
>impact for the scope should be 14cm directly above the point of aim

This results in a 100m zero for the top chevron, with the elevation set at "1".
I can upload the correct EN translation of the SVD manual somewhere if you want (or the Czech one which is far more detailed but probably not of much use to you lol).

Somethings going to happen in the next two years so lets talk about prep that everyone should have. Most governments in my area advise 72 hours minimum prep, but lets consider SHTF as well.

Minimum Physical Standards for SHTF

1.5x Bodyweight Squat
1.0x Bodyweight Bench Press (0.8x woman)
2.0x Bodyweight Deadlift

1.5 Mile(2400m) Run in under 15 min
50m Fully Clothed Swim

Have completed a 25km, 12.5kg(25lb) Ruck march

Guns/Ammo

You better have a primary arm with 1k ammo at a minimum.
For every firearm you have, you should have 1k ammo stocked up

Comms

If you haven't bought a Baofeng UV5r at a minimum, better get on that too.

Bug Out vs. Bug in

If you are bugging out, you need to have all this packed up and ready. If you are bugging in, you shouldn't consider yourself a prepper, you should consider yourself a homesteader.

posts.com:
What's everyone's local weather like?
We lost power for a week in 300C weather, now own a small generator to protect the chest freezer and fridge, plus have some light and charge small stuff like phones and laptops. Flipside is it hits -300C every year as well. Hasn't happened to me yet but the region is known for power knockouts in the winter due to ice storms that can last upwards of a week.

Summer plan is move the bed to the finished basement and maybe run a small AC at night off the generator to keep cool.
Unfortunately the genny is too small to run much in the way of heaters. The current plan is a 150w blanket in an absolute fuckton of blankets and layers, plus sleeping in clothes, plus having a gf for heat. We'll isolate one room to stay in and have a few hundred candles set aside for light+heat, with LED lanterns and headlamps for warm weather when that's not desirable.

At the moment we store 50l (10 gallons?) of gas which is enough for a few weeks if used intelligently. Hoping to invest in some solar panels and a battery bank soon.

To my mind you have to put serious effort to mod the ass end to prevent it from taking a stock. Manufacturers tend to not want to invest in tooling to do so. Tooling cost money and it shit cans sales to people that want to sbr it. Also it creates proprietary parts. So as far as I have heard, yes it can take a stock.

posts.com: Anyone else tired of the LPVO meme? I'm debating on ditching my LPVO for a fixed zoom, probably a 6x or 8x, and maybe an offset iron for close range. I still like the concept of an LPVO but in practice I only ever use the 1x or the 8x, the 2-7x serves no purpose but to get from one to the other. 90% of my .308 shooting is tiny targets at 200 yards where I prefer to have magnification anyway, the only time I use it close range is with smurf ammo. For me it would probably have the most practical use on a small game rifle for popping squirrel and rabbits at various distances

I'm a huge fan of LPVOs, but I use them on my hunting rifles and not on semiauto plinkers/fun guns. I've used a Leupold VX3-HD 1.5-5x and a Leica Amplus 1-6x a bunch on my heavier hitters, but by far my favorite and the best scope I've ever owned is a Swarovski z8i 1-8x with the 4A-IF reticle. If I were more serious about my battle rifles or ARs I'd buy 1-6 or 1-8 Leica, Zeiss, Swarovski, or Schmidt & Bender. The flexibility to have true 1x and then 6x or 8x and anything between is clutch.

posts.name: Anonymous

Polymer is durable, light and strong, resistant to corrosion, and cheaper to produce than milled/forged steel. We are past the point of this being a debate, you are just living in your own head. But that is fine, buy whatever you like.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56437694
Before ruling out polymer frames, or opting for any metal frame option, try to feel each viable option in your hand. Ergonomics, balance (I argue there is a distinction), ease of sight acquisition, etc are all hard to gauge without doing so. Preferably when considering a pistol: you could ask a friend who has one to try it out or rent one from a range; just hold one at a gun store. If you - after assessing them in person - still have difficulty choosing between similarly effective options (as per your own findings), then consider material strength and aesthetics. Narrow the list by what you would like shooting, then - within that more focused list - figure out what will last as long as at least you (possibly consider heirlooming) and what you don't mind looking at every day.

Not saying you're wrong, I mean to say there is no way for anyone to tell what your optimal 'forevergun' is. Never buy a gun before at least holding one of the same model. Preferably don't buy one of the same model without shooting it or an analogous model.
Good luck anon. Happy shopping, and a merry Christmas.

This anon is correct. The original M70s were milled receiver guns. Eventually Zastava moved to a 1.5mm stamped receiver. Yugoslavia never received the AK47 or AKM TDP so their AK development was entirely reverse engineered with changes made for their unique needs (rifle grenades and the like).

All Yugo/Serbian AK imports have been stamped including the current ZPAP.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>56433978
Oh, yeah wouldn't get the little Mini-Beryl kit they're offering. The brace they use is a 2 second job to mount yourself since it just mounts under the pistol grip. The the best option for a brace is to drill the rear trunnion for a picatinny or other mount. It's easy. Jay from MishaCo's channel made a video on how he did it.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=bvbCFvvtaWs

You'll eventually want to find a mini-Beryl rear trunnion so it doesn't matter that you're drilling into the placeholder rear trunnion. Even if you wind up selling it for some reason, the ability to mount a stock/brace easily will be a positive vs the factory setup. The other stuff they're offering isn't worth the asking price imo. They didn't drop the price on the bundle when they dropped the price on the gun itself. Just not good value.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56436243
You don't need the tab for the regular furniture. You only need it for the Beryl rail that sits over the dust cover, which you can't use with the mini Beryl because it doesn't have the slot in the rear sight base. The tabbed one is also unfinished.

Absolute worst case scenario, you have the no-tab trunnion installed but decide you want to mount the Beryl rail bad enough to modify or swap your front sight base, you can just buy one of the tabbed trunnions, knock out the tab, and install it in your already-installed rear trunnion. It's just a friction fit part. You could even make the tab with some properly sized dowel rod if the tabbed trunnions are no longer available.

If you really want to get the tabbed trunnion anyway, then go ahead. It's not a big deal either way but it won't be usable for its intended purpose without modifying/swapping your front sight base.

posts.com:
They already had decent optics in WW2 so did the design work that went into the AK-47 intentionally leave out the possibility to mount optics?
As far as I know, the AK-47 was meant to replace the submachine guns used by the Red Army, so its design objective was to be a “more effective smg” with little emphasis on long range engagement. According to the Soviet-German experience in WW2, most engagements were within 150 meters. It would have been lethal trying to engage beyond that because the opfor had snipers and what would later become DMRs like the Dragunov.
As for short range optics like the Aimpoint, it’s not feasible to equip every man with them, and if you train your army to use Aimpoints, they can’t hit shit when they stop working.
Further thinking of it, training with iron sights is better for combat because most of the accuracy comes from muscle memory and after that you’re basically just using the front sight. This should be enough for the intended engagement range.
So did the AK-47 design intentionally incorporate a “safety feature” making it difficult to mount optics so that some idiot general won’t get any foolish ideas about how to use the weapon? They kept the design in the AK-74 that came years after the Dragunov, so clearly this was to stress the fact that you shouldn’t try to engage the enemy beyond reasonable iron sight range as you’d be going against DMRs and sniper rifles. For the same reason you should probably not mount optics on smgs and pistols, because it may hurt your accuracy with combat proven iron sights. Do tacticool people understand this at all?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Poorly. Lead will just melt against any plates. Soft armour with no sort of solid padding will be painful though, but it still won't penetrate.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56436425
Soft kevlar will cushion the impact, but stop the slug as long as it's rated IIIa or better. How much it would cushion depends on a lot of factors, but there's a possibility of the wearer getting the wind knocked out of their lungs or even get some broken ribs. It would not be a good time for sure.
Hard plates like level III or IV steel or ceramic would simply shatter the slug and disperse the energy on a wide enough surface that it might give the wearer a shove, but not much beyond that. As the slug breaks up it can also spall along the length and width of the plate causing some cuts, bruises and potentially embedding small fragments of itself into exposed flesh. This is still quite unpleasant so don't try it at home.

Well they do have 308s in their arsenals. It’s just that all things considered, the benefits of 5.56 outweigh its shortcomings and it emerges as the superior general issue cartridge.

6.8SPC is a dumb middle-of-the-road cartridge that does nothing well. It’s heavier and harsher recoiling than 5.56, performance is gimped from Remington fuckign the chamber up, and has a shit ogive and shit trajectory despite improved long range performance being what prompted its development. Even if it was superior to 5.56, it would have to be better by a significant enough margin to justify the logistical nightmare of moving to a new caliber with new weapons.

I say 6.8SPC is dumb as someone who owns a 6.8SPC rifle lol

They should have scaled the 6.8x51 down to to a 5.56 sized case that takes a .224 bullet. Make the whole thing a little longer than a 5.56 to accommodate a much longer and heavier FABRL-style projectile. This gives you the sectional density and velocity of 6.8x51 (and thus it’s trajectory and penetration characteristics), except it’s way better because now the bullet has a much finer shape (higher BC) and the whole thing weighs about as much as 5.56. No heavier ammo, no heavier or bigger guns, same 30rd mag capacity, better trajectory, penetration, and energy retention.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56422050
>How is it compared to the P-01? Is the orange one any better?
I have both a Shadow 2 and P-01, they aren't really comparable. The P-01 is a carry/duty gun and the Shadow 2 is a dedicated competition gun.

The P-01 has a light-weight alloy frame, it's nice and compact, it has low profile combat sights, and a decocker for real world use. The hammer springs are typical and heavy enough to reliably set off even hard surplus primers. Everything about it revolves around practicality.

The Shadow 2 frame is a chunk of steel as heavy as the IPSC/USPSA rule set allows withe the dust cover intentionally fat to damped recoil. The grips are aggressive with a fuck huge paddle on the mag release. The safety is purposefully the lowest profile they make because you're not allowed to use it competition. Sights are tall, adjustable, and fast with a blacked out rear and fiber front. It also isn't drop safe since they took the firing pin block to make a better trigger. The hammer springs are lighter as a trade off for trigger pull over primer reliability.

The Shadow 2 Orange is definitely better. It has a barrel buffer and tighter, hand finishing on the slide-frame fit and trigger. But, unless you're a hardcore and experienced competition shooter, it's not really worth the extra $700. For less money, you could get a Tac Sport Orange or TS 2 Green for less and have a better range gun, but one that would be in a higher competition division.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56434746
>Could've been the ammo quality
nah. the gun was just beat to shit.

the gun uses a locking block, as the gun wears it wears unevenly on the sides of the locking block, that's fine for the first locking block since it wears with the gun. but when you replace it all other locking blocks will receive uneven force and wear faster. if a locking block breaks it can do damage to the frame. they should be replaced every 20k rounds, maybe even sooner if it's 9mm NATO, I have heard that they'd let the locking blocks break before replacing them in the military. Real lax recoil spring replacements too. Magazines too.

Ben Stoger (a competition shooter) has beretta 92s that have over 100k rounds through them and working as if they were brand new. They'll last forever if they were taken care of (recoil spring, hammer spring replacements at 5k rounds, locking block replacements at 20k (or less), etc) and also not shooting 9mm NATO only.

>I've read online that they can be absolute jam-machines and malfunction constantly
that's because the range rentals are shot to shit, poorly maintained, and fed the bottom of the barrel ammo (reloads and shit)

the Deagle uses a gas system so you must avoid using bare lead or partially jacketed ammunition in it or you will plug up the gas port, .357 mag and .44 magnum ammo are revolver rounds which do not care about pressure curves so you have a wide variety of ammunition/pressures available - the deagle is very particular in the pressure curve of the ammunition due to the gas system. It's picky. The .50 AE is the most reliable since all .50 AE ammo is specifically made for the Deagle. Many people have reliable .357s and .44s though, they just find a ammo that it likes and stick with that.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56436621
Gen 3s still used the single coil plastic RSA. Sometime during Gen 4 Glock updated the interval, and stopped teaching their armorers to automatically replace RSAs every 5k, and to only do so if it failed the battery test.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56436655
>stopped teaching their armorers to automatically replace RSAs every 5k
>so now they last longer
what

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56436761
They moved to a steel, double coil RSA in Gen 4. Despite this, a lot of armorers were still replacing them at the old interval of 5k, largely because the swap takes 20 seconds and armorers like to feel like they've done something.

During Gen 4, Glock stopped teaching their armorers to automatically replace the RSA at the old interval of 5k rounds, and to only replace them if ejection is erratic, malfs are happening, or the gun is failing the "return to battery with gun pointed at ceiling" test. The new RSAs have been shown to go 10k-15k no problem, especially on the larger guns.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56436801
I should add, the Gen 3 RSAs could also go beyond 5k rounds, though not to the same degree as the new RSA. Glock just told their armorers to replace them early out of preponderance of caution, and the plastic part was quite cheap.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56431277
If.
The simple fact is, chemical propulsion is really simple and really good. Finding a chemical composition whose energy you can extract into electric form is much harder than finding one that can simply be released with your standard exothermic reaction. So I repeat: we may get much better batteries yet, but we may just as well get much better chemical propellants.
And it does objectively require less tech and less complexity to make it happen. You will always need a feed system to get new bullets into the barrel, but with chemical propulsion you don't need electronics to access the battery or to control the acceleration of the bullet. Just a feed/reload system, a trigger and a firing pin.

>>56431070
A battery or capacitor that can hold enough energy to fire multiple magazines worth of ammunition, and that can discharge it quickly enough for combat rates of fire, is a fucking bomb. Current cartridges separate the energy storage into discrete units for each projectile. And then 20-50 of those units, which are already well isolated from each other, housed together in another container. If your gun can go through hundreds or thousands of rounds off the energy stored in its battery you're getting into the flamethrower problem. That shit gets ruptured and ALL of that energy is getting violently released at once.
Might see battery/capacitor powered sporting arms if the tech greatly improves, but absolutely fucking never in military arms that have to deal with being shot at unless we stumble on some thermodynamics breaking zero point energy bs.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56435024
Internal combustion guns?
it isn't impossible, gasoline has ~10 times more energy per weight although after some very quick and rough calcs the energy efficiency would be more like 5 (or less) times more than gunpowder (with a 300bar air tank), or somewhat better but with far more "moving mass" than a normal gun (without a tank with high pressure).
It isn't hard to do some better calcs but the current gunpowder tech is very streamlined when it comes to lowest mass and complexity for the gun and ammo. Accuracy and reliability are far harder with something more complex.
Although it's possible the problem is weight, to make it useful you would need a compressor (30-300 bar in my quick calcs) and a engine (more than 5 HP), that alone would weight far more than a normal gun with 10 magazines.
Maybe for larger systems would be ok. But again, if you can fit a complex engine and compressor (can't be done without high pressure air) you're better just carrying normal ammo that's simpler, cheap enough and far more reliable.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>56426479
Those sailors are a landing party from the protected cruiser USS Olympia, and the soldiers are from the US 339th Infantry Regiment. They are part of the North Russia Expeditionary Force, which landed in Murmansk and Arkhangelsk Russia in order to support the White forces of the Russian Civil War and to prevent war material sent to those ports from falling into Bolshevik hands. The NREF was issued US-made Mosin-Nagant rifles that had been purchased by the Imperial Russian government and had been in transit to Russia when the Bolsheviks took over. The Mosins were held in Britain, then issued to the NREF in place of their US M1917 rifles because large supplies of 7.62x54R ammunition were also present in Arkhangelsk and Murmansk and it was thought it would simplify supply issues. It is interesting to see sailors off Olympia carrying them, because I have a picture of Olympia sailors taken earlier in the year when they first arrived in Murmansk and they have M1903s.

>>56426494
Remington Arms and Westinghouse produced them for the Russians, but the rifles purchased by the US government weren't used to arm the NREF. Those rifles had already been shipped to Britain when the Bolsheviks took over and the British sequestered them while they tried to sort out the political situation in Russia.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56431918
I have an M96. Frankly it's the same as any Mauser, check the quality check for matching. Swedes were autistic about markings so almost every part is numbered, and most guns will have all important parts match at the least, total matching also not uncommon. There's so much less to worry about on Swedish guns because they saw no war except some going to Finland to have a little fun, and it is incredibly easy to find them in immaculate condition. I mean, the fucking Swedes are the only people autistic enough to tell Germany, "No, you don't do it good enough so we want to make our own Mausers. Also use our steel for those sample guns you're making us, because it's better." And be right on both counts. They have the stock disks which were used by armories to record the barrel quality, you can see if your gun was rebarrelled there. Bear in mind the information stamped on the stock is literally decades out of date, so trying to guess the current quality off of that is silly.

Personally, I would go for the M38, it's a very cool rifle at a more reasonable size than the M96. I also really like the m1894 carbines, a lot of them were made pre-1899, and therefore not legally a modern firearm so you can have it shipped to your door no background check no FFL without a C&R, which is pretty fucking neato. The M/94 was so far ahead of its time. ~18" barrel, 6.5 caliber rifle in 1894. It's over a hundred years later and people are finally rediscovering how great that is with AR10s and the like.

>>56432027
thanks alot for the info anon. If you are looking for an FN Model 50 i can only give you a bit of info, not much out there on these rifles. In the 50s FN made a contract with Colombia, since columbia got a ton of 30-06 surplus from the good ol USA for a good price. They made their last military mausers: The FN Model 50 in 30-06. They have a longer magazine and action and a cutout in the Receiver to accomodate longer 30-06 loads. They also made the stripper clip groove wider, i think for Springfield clips originally. They also send some of these Rifles to the congo, and kept some for their own army in reserve. The Colombian ones got the colombian crest on the receiver, the belgian ones the crown and the kings name in short. The colombians also converted some old 1924 Rifles to 30-06, those will have a "30" behind the stripper clip groove. A lot of the belgian ones will have the crown and other markings scrubbed off like mine. Also they made these with a grey-green type of coating for the colombian navy and the congo and black paint for the colombian and belgian army. They made two types: The shorter 1930 pattern and the longer 1924 pattern, mine is a 1924 pattern with a straight bolt handle and 23 inch barrel. They should take K98, VZ24 and Preduzece and FN bayonets. One very characteristic thing is a special buttplate with a wave pattern for more grip. Generally the "Congo" models saw alot of action and are worn accordingly, the belgian and colombian army ones are normally in great condition. Again, FN made these long after the war with the best materials and 30 years of experience, they are great shooters. Oh also, some (like mine) were refurbished before being sold to the civilian market, mine has a non matching stock in a great color and with FN Arsenal markings, thats normal as well. Also also, some have a 2000 meter rear sight, some have a 1900. Not sure whats up with that, i think they reused old parts for the rear sight

posts.name: Anonymous

>>56432042
>Why wouldn't Russia just use the secure open-source solutions?
At this level, when you have NSA/GCHQ/etc as an enemy, there's a very justified concern that even "secure, open-source" cryptographic systems are insecure.

Like, it's unlikely, and it's something that even NSA itself has admitted it won't try to do, but when you're a Russian the concern is still there. I remember back when Snowden's disclosures were initially happening, there were references to a "high level cryptographic break" and people were freaking out that RSA (the system that tells you 4chan.org is actually 4chan.org and not the FBI among many other things) or AES (symmetrical encryption, used on radios so more applicable here) was broken by NSA.

It turned out that they had compromised a few things that let them, in some cases, break internet traffic but there wasn't ever any proof that AES or similar was broken. Still, it's a concern.

So yeah because of this quite a few countries have made algorithms like https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kuznyechik and it's not infeasible that somewhere along the way NSA and friends have introduced a vulnerability and are collecting traffic.

>>56435858
>were these key tables that were designed in this weird way that looked deliberate.
No, not exactly. I mean you're 99% right and I get what you mean but there's a bit more context to that: The S boxes inside the algorithm itself, which are basically predetermined, publicly known variables the encryption uses to mix the key with the plaintext (just explaining it for other anons) were given to NSA for review. NSA looked at them, tweaked them a bit, then returned them without explanation. NSA was asked WHY they changed the S boxes, since the changes they made, made no sense to even expert cryptographers, and NSA refused to comment.

And then yeah, it turned out 10 years later they changed it slightly to protect against (from memory) differential cryptanalysis, which wasn't a publicly known technique at that point. I wouldn't be surprised if some people who reviewed it had a clue or even knew outright but kept their mouths shut.

Point is, NSA isn't ALWAYS going to work against you but they certainly don't go out of your way to make you trust them.

I'm new to Guns. And my question is in line with cheap vs expensive.

Hypothetically if we took 2 different model AR-15's and secured them to were they would fire perfect with a use a of a machine then would cause Gun-A ($2000) with a 16in barrel shooting 5.56 have tighter groupings at 50 yards over Gun-B ($700) with the same barrel length/specs and ammo type?

What makes the better difference? Is the same bullet getting launched out of the same length metal grade tube.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Better metals, better harmonics, better quality in rifling uniformity, longer life of barrel is usually stuff more expensive barrels have

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56433543
If they both have the same twist rate firing the same ammo, it depends. Gun A and B may both be using barrels manufactured by the same manufacturer like FN, Green Mountain, etc. It's not a definite answer; for all we know, the price difference could all be in brand name or who knows, maybe the cost difference is QC and nicer parts. Or if you're buying from some companies, you're paying for the rollmark (logo) and specific model; some people really want to own certain variations of an AR and don't care if it costs a couple thousand. What I can tell you is that barrel quality is (one of the) biggest parts of accuracy. The less rough the rifling is, the better the tolerances in the chamber, the better - usually.

Price doesn't necessarily change how well your parts are made. Some companies have shitty barrels while cheaper competitors might have a nicer barrel. All depends who we're comparing Don't get a shitty $90 scope either if you're not using irons. I recommend learning on irons but if you don't use iron sights, Leupold makes nice scopes and for $350 you can have their cheapest ($300) scope and rings (~$30). Red dots, I have no clue.

Previous >>56355642
nobody made a new thread edition

Resource on what these spec terminology mean
https://www.nite-walker.com/post/2019/11/21/specs-for-dummies-101
https://apollogearco.com/blogs/news/night-vision-specs-explained
https://gloomgroup.com/blogs/night-vision-info/night-vision-specifications-understanding-what-they-mean

You shouldn't be chasing for spec values but they do exist and if you wanted to know what "better spec" values are there's a way to know which unit is desirable over another.
Most retailers won't post this info as they build NVDs to order, first come first serve, and depending on their grading scale of high, mid, low tier it may differ from retailers. If a retailer offer a “ready to ship” fully built units they will list the spec values. Hand select is an option from retailers that will try to match to your spec requirements.

Some reputable retailers:
https://www.jrhenterprises.com/
https://nvisionoptics.com/
https://www.customnightvision.com/
https://gooningear.com/
https://apollogearco.com
https://blackphasetactical.com/
https://steeleindustries.com/

SNR: signal to noise ratio, the amount of signal the tube can make compared to the noise
EBI: equivalent background information, how much false image appears in the screen through which the actual image has to show, sort of a noise floor of sorts
Halo: How big the circle of bloom is around lights
Photocathode Sensitivity: How sensitive the photocathode is
LP Resolution: Line pair res of the center of the image as measure against a standardized chart

If one spec is shit it negates the rest, if you have a halo of 2.0 it kinda fucks on an EBI of 0.20 if you want to do any kind of shooting and it's all a balance game

The numbers to meet or beat are
EBI under 1, preferably under 0.6 being great, 0.1 is gucci
Halo under 1, anything under 0.7 is awesome
SNR, over 25 anything over 30 is gucci
Photocathode, 1900+ is pretty great, 2500+ is stellar
Resolution of 64+ is good, 72+ is gucci

>>56431908
5.56 is better as a cartridge purely for suppression due to weight/round considerations. Similarly 5.56 enjoys an advantage in terms of external ballistics making suppressing or even striking targets in the 300-500m range more likely due to lower drop. OTOH 7.62x39 offers considerably superior barrier performance to 5.56 and significantly better potential for terminal performance within 200m or so, due to its mass.
>inb4 muh m67 vs m193
it isnt the 70s and we arent in the military.

Bottom line, both are plenty adequate if you choose decent loads. Both have their advantages. People like to downplay 7.62s advantages(excluding the occasional fanboy). Personally id still choose 5.56 for most uses simply due to availability reasons, my own personal needs, and the fact that its usually on the bleeding edge of current ammo tech.
