posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Aight fags sit down and shut up. A combat robot would need the following:
>humanoid size
It has to fit through doorways and places people can run, walk, crawl, or otherwise access. It has to get into vehicles and rooms or whatever. It doesn't have to be exactly human-shaped, but it has to be about the same size as a person.
>three-sided design
Tripod legs, with a retractable wheel for smooth surfaces.
Three arms with at least four articulating fingers.
Three sensor modules. Each module comes with a telephoto lens, wide angle lens, photointensifier unit, and thermal camera. The modules are wedge-shaped and each cover 120 degree FOV, with some overlap from the wider-angle cameras. Each module would have microphone, both directional and wide-range, and a kestrel system.
>Weapons
It would have a main rifle in something like 6.5 Creedmoor mounted in the bot's center of mass on a triple gymbal, so three articulating arms that synchronize their movements. The system can still aim if two of the gymbals are inoperative. It would have a mortar-like system down the spine with an "abdomen" grenade store, and a small caliber (like 9x19) high ROF weapon.
>armor
Lots of hot pressed UHMWPE and titanium diboride boron-enriched boron ceramic strike faces (wrapped in one layer of carbon fiber weave for strike face integrity) with hot pressed UHMWPE backers on critical systems.

Hard to kill, redundant systems, sees everything in every direction, inherently stable shooting platform, fits everywere a person can.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56407011
>Heavy duty opposing EWAR capabilities
While the military thought that making them autonomous would counter this the units started acting 'unpredictably' and in ways that went counter to established policies (you can decide if that's just a programming bug or something trying to attain sentience/independence, but if you do that could steal a lot of focus in your story).

>non-humanoid designs would have trouble outside of very specific environments, especially FIBUA/FISH scenarios
Those areas were built explicitly for the human body to move around in. If your robot isn't at least vaguely humanoid it's going to have trouble there. You can design around that, to an extent, but you're always going to be making compromises that negatively affect *something* about the final product. Leads nicely on to

>Humanoid designs prove to be too maintenance intensive
Yes, Boston Dynamics can do it, but in very nicely maintained and cleaned static environments. Ask any infantry engineer; shit breaks. Shit breaks all the goddamn time. Shit breaks in ways that it was specifically designed not to break in. If a soldiers kit breaks on a mission then that increases the risk to him and lowers his effectiveness. If a bipedal robot breaks you've got at least an instant mission/mobility kill. Granted it's not a great argument if you think about it too much, but it should work as a handwave if you're light on the details.

Were you thinking of using them as drones or as fully aware and human tier AI? There would be different options for not using either one, but with what you've posted there that should be a good starting point.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56415959
Agreed. A while ago a lab subjected cars built between 1980 and 2014 to repeated EMP strikes both while running and turned off. They discovered that 90% of vehicles suffered zero effects, and the 10% that did just lost shit like power windows, or the navigation console quit working. Basically none of the cars became inoperable, and if they did the repairs required were minor. Turns out most of the failsafes we build into our tech to prevent various devices interfering with eachother also protects from EMP. The biggest things hit by EMP are... big things like power grids. Even then, getting the grid back up would be expensive and a huge pain in the ass, but its not like we'd suddenly be set back to the year 1850. Shit would suck, but it wouldn't be the end of the world. Just a major disruption to it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56407011
>robot soldier
>I'm writing a sci-fi story and I struggle to find a reason not to include them in it
The EASY OBVIOUS WAYS is to make AI and hacking ridiculously efficient.

Each side have "AI" and enough processing power that any encryption is pointless.
The AI themselves are simultaneously the most powerful thing they could have but also the most fragile.
The AI codes is so sophisticated it code itself (without going sentient) and no human would have the time to double check the codes.

So WHAT, IF, the enemy managed to infiltrate your country AI(s)?
Every design made using that AI could have off-switch used by the enemy. Or maybe it could change Friend or Foe recognition.
You'd need several AI copy, cross-checking each other regularly for hidden code, unable to receive data that wasn't itself double-checked.
The paranoia would drive you and your soldiers crazy, is this Dog-level AI truly safe? Will it turn against us with the flip of a switch?

The only AI that cannot be hacked (yet) are human.
I'm not saying "don't use sophisticated system", I'm saying, "make every single system human-centric".

A killer-robot cannot be trusted.
But you can trust an exoskeleton built to only accept very specific form of data and only obey its user, even if he have to go against his own superior.
In fact, knowing you could kill your boss with the weapon he entrust you with, show trust.

END

>>56427188
I was imagining this as a fully autonomous advanced AI-controlled robot. Basically something with very little ability to be hacked externally. Imagine a bot that is doing constant video processing to identify movements (even while subtracting its own) and thermal signatures; you barely poke your head out and it's spotted some movement, if not thermal. Within milliseconds, it's decided to aim a telephoto lens at you, then it identifies "guy poking his head out". Depending of SOP, it could already be moving its servos to aim a weapon in your direction and it hasn't even been 10 milliseconds. At this point, it's waiting to see if you have a weapon. An eternety later, you finally raise your rifle to a position where it can spot and identify a weapon, and it's already firing.

So mobility depends on what gait this thing chooses. Three legged gaits are weird, but there are a variety of gaits that go from slow and energy efficient, to simply tucking one leg and running on two for higher speed at a cost of regular two-legged gait energy expenditure.

With high end bot to bot encryption, teams of these could coordinate. They only accept transmission from robot members of their own team. "Hacking" current encryption is still computationally impossible while this level of AI is not (even if we haven't figured out how to "program" such AI, there's nothing computationally "impossible" about it at this point). Teams of these would be scarier; you mortar or snipe one of these bots, they've already triangulated your mortar position using each other's microphones. Just about the only way I can think of defeating these things is planting explosives and baiting them somewhere days or weeks later.

posts.com:
>>56431053
IMHO a big problem is that the AR-15 action just isn't really strong enough to get the most out of the cartridge. The case head is quite a bit bigger so by the time the bolt face is machined out enough to accomodate the .458's case head there is not much material left around the locking lugs. This means that most commercial .458 ammo is loaded very light (say, 30,000 psi or under) and even that cracks bolts. To get the most out of it you need a stronger platform, but there aren't many of those around. The only one that comes to mind is CMMG. They used to call it the "Anvil", I'm not sure what they call it now. It's basically an AR-10 size bolt head but with an AR-15 length action. That is strong enough that you can load the Socom to its max potential but there aren't any other options like that which I know of, and even then you're pretty much forced to handload since off the shelf ammo is cucked for the average gun built on an AR-15 bolt head.

There hasn't been anything approaching parity since the 60's, anon. The might of the Soviet Union was a fairy tale after that. Every time that we watched Soviet equipment and doctrine fail, it was one excuse after another.

>muh monkey models
>muh training ammo
>muh equipment designed for eastern Europe
>muh equipment not operated by Russians

They believed their bullshit because they had to. If their citizens understood just how militarily and economically disadvantaged they were, they'd revolt. Likewise, we also believed their bullshit, because our government told us that it was real. Our government believed that it was real because that's what the MIC told them. The MIC told them that because without a credible opponent, the defense industry doesn't get funded. But it was all bullshit, and there's no denying it anymore.

Things got even worse after the collapse of the USSR. Most Russians with intelligence or competence moved west for the better living conditions. What's left is a failed petrostate with an economy smaller than that of Texas, and until 2022, your elected leaders pitched them as an existential threat to democracy.

Most of those people are still in office. Remember their lies when they're up for re-election, and contemplate who the next bogeyman will be, now that the Russian narrative has lost all credibility.

>>56416298
I'm very tempted to buy a stocked Marauder pistol in .22 for squirrels, I just need to get some other guns first. I think I'm going to get a .22lr suppressor for hunting, then a PCP, despite the fact that the other way around would probably make more sense. Wait times for stamps are a bitch, though, so the sooner I start the process, the better. I have other air rifles, though, so it's a niche already partially filled. One partially filled by the Swarm, which I wish were smaller, but I love the quick loading. The other partially filled by the 1377, which I wish was mag fed, a pcp, and .22. You know, basically a Marauder with a stock.

I figure that buying a marauder with a decent scope will allow me to fill a role with what would otherwise would only be able to be filled by a takedown or an SBR. Pistols (firearms) wouldn't fill the role either as semi auto .22lr pistols are illegal to hunt with in this state despite semi auto .22lr rifles being totally fine. Bring a Marauder in a small hard (or well padded) case and if no foxes turn up while I'm lugging around my .223, I can at least take it out to shoot some squirrels or maybe even groundhogs. Solves a problem I have, choosing what to take on a specific day. I can take a semi auto .22lr rifle as well as a .223 for fox, but it's hell on the back having to also bring all my other junk, including a little take-down seat if it's wet and cold out.

I've posted this little guy before, but this is my first gun pic with him. He usually doesn't sit still long enough for one of these.
If anyone recognizes him, I have a little update on his health situation. He's got FIP, basically kitty covid. Lymph nodes swollen, liver swollen to double it's normal size, jaundiced, etc. We have him on some experimental treatment, isn't FDA approved yet. Seems to be working so far, he's regained normal color in his nose and the other cat isn't treating him like he's sick anymore. Lymph nodes going down too. This was just after the first shot of the stuff, the treatment is supposed to take a few months to clear all this up. He doesn't like needles as we've found, so we've ordered some pills of the same stuff that can be broken up in his soft food. Those come in tomorrow.
He hasn't really changed in his normal behaviors, so I think he's gonna pull through. This treatment has like an 80% to near 100% success rate, percentage of failure just means it won't work. This should work though since he's reacting to it.

can't really say they were the same way for my family's experience. my gramps had cousins who still lived in Norway when the Germans invaded, the Wehrmacht came onto their farm and took all of their horses (about a dozen of them), which they needed for their plows to plant the crops which they survived on. without any horses, they would've starved. one of my gramps' cousins went into the Germans' camp and asked for his horses back, telling them that he and his brother would starve without them. they gave him one horse out of the dozen or so they stole. pretty shitty of them imo

Norway got completely fucked over by the occupation of the Nazis, they completely destroyed the Norwegian economy during their time in power (apparently the damage the Nazis did was worse than in any other occupied Western country), and the whole lebensborn shit they did also introduced a bunch of issues. I grew up in Norway for a time, most of the old folk who grew up in the occupation were super sensitive about food and would never waste anything that could be eaten since they starved a bunch in childhood. so I can't really say that Germans had much respect for the country that my family's from, except for getting grossly horny over Norwegian women like the modern Somali asylum seeker.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56425881
Well, I am Norwegian, and what you say doesn't really add up. Now, I'm not going to pretend that the Germans were saints and that Norwegians were living carefree during the war, given that we were actually occupied by an enemy force in a time when modern rules of war did not really apply, but considering the circumstances and the horrific things that happened elsewhere in Europe during that war, Norwegians were treated generally well.
If you're wondering what my personal perspective is based on, two of my grandparents were civilians during the war, and only interacted with the nearby Germans, including an HQ next to their home and an interment camp for Russian POWs and political prisoners, while my other grandparents were part of the resistance and met during the war. My grandfather on that side of the family narrowly escaped the Gestapo on more than one occasion and got shot up by British Mosquitos when he fled to England, and his later wife, my grandmother, had nothing good to say about the Germans, but still told me outright that the regular German soldiers never did anything to anyone, and acted properly. That said, some of my grandfather's compatriots were caught and brutalized by the Gestapo during interrogation, though they survived the war.
Obviously there were other issues, like food being confiscated for the war effort and Norwegians being forced to rely on food stamps, with items like cheese, sugar and meat becoming luxury items (and boy do I have some weird stories to tell in that regard), not to mentioned the scorched earth policy in northern Norway when the Red Army invaded, and the decimation of Telavåg. However, most of the war crimes were committed by the Gestapo, and Terboven's personal army.
However, fewer than 1800 Norwegian civilians died during the occupation, and from what I recall, about half of those were killed due to Allied bombing raids, including one of my grandmother's cousins, when the Brits bombed an elementary school.

Same guy as >>56426143
I read over your post again, and I find it absolutely bizarre that you would claim that the Germans took your family's horses to plow some imaginary German fields, considering I can't imagine a scenario where that would be applicable. The Germans got their food from the Norwegian population, and from what I recall (though I might be mistaken), they actually paid for the food.
A lot of Norwegians, many of whom were accused of being collaborators (including some distant relatives of mine who are obscenely wealthy), made a fortune during the war, because actually working with the Germans was extremely profitable, if you were in the right field. Another issue that I've been told was common was Norwegian farmers refusing to sell their produce to other Norwegians, because the Germans paid better, which in turn led to the collaborators being threatened and beaten by locals if they refused to sell, or just outright killed in rare circumstances.

As for the horses in your post, if the Germans actually did take them from your family, it was certainly not for farming, but for military transportation.

The more autonomous drone become, the less they need new orders. Someday they will have orders letting them choose who to kill.

>Armor is a tiny fraction of what a soldier carries right now
Nothing against robot mule but actually carrying enough armor to protect you from shrapnel&shockwave is going to seriously impede your mobility unless you've spent millions into the exo-armor and it cost more in maintenance than single-use soldier (exaggerating but still).

It's all about limbs complexity. Human's limbs are articulated around their bones, the powered EXO-skeleton need to match the center of rotation of the limb without access to it. If it's only one Degree of Freedom it's ok, it can be parallel, once you get above 2 now that's a nightmare and you aren't even trying yet to make it form-fitting "bioarmor".
And you WILL need powered arms so your soldier don't stay stuck after jumping in a trench because he can't lift 3x his mass.

You may not need to carry APC-level armor but if you want to have armored arms/legs it will require very bulky/complicated power-armor.

If I remember right something like 2/3rd of all combat medevacs in Iraq/Afghanistan were because of muscular-skeletal injuries from the loads that modern soldiers bear on the battlefield. DOD is currently looking into all sorts of shit to bring down the weight of the modern soldier. A big part of that could be basically modern pack mechs which can carry stuff like medical supplies, ammo, batteries, etc.

Means soldiers carry less, perform better in combat, expend less energy, get less non-combat injuries.

Won't be used in armored formations or anything, but it would be useful to light infantry. I think there were some tests a year or two backs on a robot that could carry something like 80lbs and it went quite well.

Even today you don't have drones very low to the ground if you are far away. They have to fly higher to get signal the farther you get and the further you go it makes them vulnerable to EW.

Nap of the Earth or ground level movements from a person or using signal from a radio tower will only be 4-40km depending on height of the thing broadcasting to the drone/robot. And you want to use this transmission because these are the least vulnerable to jamming as the second you start using sattelite or gps guided drones EW can start fucking with both the satellite in the space above to confuse the drone as the gps antenna will pick up wrong information and actually jam to prevent you from controlling the drone/robot.

Being able to control a drone from across the ocean against a near peer adversary is a fantasy that will not happen in any realistic setting. And if it were to be done it would require repeaters from a FOB and the Ukraine was has shown that radio silence is key for fobs as broadcasting the location of where you do things is kinda bad

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56427520
>Radio tower support HQ video for hundred thousands simultaneously, our military need is insignificant given today's tech.
Actually, military field HQs are never dealing with more than a thousand transmissions at any given moment. Most field units will use long range radio sparingly as they can be detected by RDF. Most of the time they'll use short range comms that aren't powerful enough for HQ to hear.

>The number given by "previous anon" (you seem new) was a ridiculous "only 2 drones and saturate".
Same person, I'm just not splitting my attention between work and you.

>micro-drone swarm (who do not each send HQ video feed), wingmen and disposable remote.
Loyal Wingman is basically how you want to use drones. The controller is close enough that jamming becomes a lot harder and there's less decision making for the AI. You can also reduce the amplitude so that only the local drones can hear. The issue is that the controller is now in the field and needs something to keep him alive.

So what you do is have 10 suits of power armor, give 1 to a human, and rig the other 9 to function autonomously but look like a man in power armor.

>The "previous anon" who seem to think handheld/expendable mine jammer are good enough to counter anything named drone.
More precisely, the argument is that jamming is a factor of distance and if the drones are being commanded from hundreds of miles away it becomes a lot easier to jam.

>Yes but civilian need is luxurious for military.
Doesn't actually apply here. Military units regularly use EMCON so they don't generate that much radio noise to begin with. Drones can't use EMCON without loosing adaptability so they're essentially in the civilian ballpark.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56429706
>We do still have radio silence protocol but that's for special case or soviet-old enemy.
Actually, basic radio discipline says if you don't need to say anything then don't say anything.

>More an extra from being able to make autonomous drone.
>The Iron-man fan need to know that if the suit can effectively combat autonomously, then it is a robot carrying human and you might as well make clothes-*cough*Terminator*cough*-testing robots.
Semi-autonomous. Drones would still need someone to plan tactics and spot targets that aren't actively shooting at them. You can tell a drone to move there and shoot that but when it comes to actually planning and using tactics the answers are often ambiguous and computers are terrible with ambiguity.

>That's only valid if the signal is without relay and weaker than a jammer positioned in the right direction
The formula for signal strength is amplitude/(distance^2) so being closer matters a lot more than being more powerful.

>That's what I'm saying, military don't need that level of luxury, less is more than enough.
Luxury nothing, the data is padded with redundancies and deniable encryption to fight E-War efforts.

>Drones only send as much data as you've asked them to in the first place, short, more or less encrypted, already processed targeted data, you don't need nonstop raw HQ video.
You kinda do. Imagine recognition is still one of the hardest and most processor intensive tasks computers have. It actually makes more sense to send the data back to a server farm to run target recognition neural networks over rather than try to install a neural network on every drone. More secure too since a drone could be captured and it's programming analyzed.

Again, no sh*t. Who know what this discussion will look like if we have AI capable of say replace a tank-commander? or quantum computer making a joke of most encryption methods?

>so being closer matters a lot more than being more powerful.
If you can afford to be that close.
If we are talking of a micro-drone floating above you with grenades, sure a weak jammer might do if the the drone is civilian or too small/cheap to get around it.
If we are talking of UAV with missiles it will take powerful heavy specialized equipment to jam communication & without jamming yourself.

>Image recognition
You misunderstand how we "train" AI with neural networks or other method, so they DON'T need to call a super calculator every time.
This is why smartphone are capable of recognizing human face without needing direct link to the world's face database (hopefully clean of gorilla bias).
We already have cases where small device identify image or fake/decoy better than human eyes will ever be able to.

>More secure too since a drone could be captured and it's programming analyzed.
Easier said than done, it take top tier skills and equipment to:
- read a memory without the code/OS meant to read it, worse if you broke the system or it auto-wipe on crash.
- decrypt/de-compile the executable code
- obtain useful info (the enemy won't include a labeled switch-off code just for you)
- do it fast
If it was that easy the CIA wouldn't have begged for a way to hack an Iphone.
It's probably easier to obtain the code by attacking the weakest link: Human (spy/hack...etc) and it's harder if you don't have expert in drone-building on your side.

>>56429016

I wouldn't necessarily call the Su-57 non-functional; it's aerodynamic performance is roughly equal to the rest of of the flanker family, it's engines and avionics are about where russian tech is predicted to be (10-15 years behind the west), and it does have known RCS-reduction features (convex panelling, recursive shapes, internal weapons bays, etc.). At some point, there probably was a genuine effort to produce a stealth fighter- although like all modern Russian procurement programs it inexorably succumbed to underfunding, embezzlement and industrial brain-drain until it could no longer perform to specifiation, or be produced in numbers at all.

Really, if the plane was given a decent RAM coating, the engines were moved closer together and the intakes were s-ducted it's detection range would probably halve. Even if Sukhoi just fixed it's internal weapons bays, it's lowered RCS compared to other russian aircraft would make it a good SEAD platform. Not to anywhere near the extent the F-35/22 are, where where it could bypass SAM installations entirely and strike command centers, but good enough to sling ARMs at S-300 installations from relative safety. Sadly, soviet aerospace found itself adopted by a glorified banana republic, which itself will likely cease to exist within a decade and with it, the last remenants of the old design bureaus and everything that they could've created otherwise. Oh well.

posts.name: Resident Wumbologist
posts.com:
>>56431338
They are OK and I highly endorse them as a great option for poorfags.

The prices they sell at are hard to beat (in your case free) and the quality of most parts used is pretty good. Barrels tend to be on the cheap end so don't expect match grade accuracy, but they aren't terrible by any means. They shoot about on par with most non-ARs such as the current gen Ruger Mini-14, and plenty accurate enough for practical minute-of-steel-plate shooting you are going to want to do anyway.
Another tricky but is assembly. They can be slapped together sometimes because PSA sells these things in high volumes at low margins and the workers that put them together aren't paid a whole lot, nor are they true gunsmiths per se. It's a good idea to double check things such as gas key/castle nut staking and the ever annoying roll pins. Most are ok, but occasionally you get some missed step that slipped through the cracks and the rifle shoots a small part loose. Fixable but annoying.

Are they good?
That's kind of like asking if a modern economy car is good. It's amazing by the standards of a comparable car from 20-30 years ago but it's still an economy car.
Modern budget ARs such as PSA are amazing for what they cost. They are way better, cheaper and often both than what we had available back in the day but there is room for further improvement nowadays. The good thing is that if you want to you can upgrade as you go, but that's not necessary for now. Just like buying a Honda Civic when you just got your license, drive it stock for a bit first and enjoy it as is before you start tinkering.

>>56432268
>Barrels tend to be on the cheap end so don't expect match grade accuracy, but they aren't terrible by any means
US military considers 4 MOA accuracy acceptable for duty M4s. Your average nitrided PSA barrel will shoot well under that with quality match loads. Barrels (even expensive ones) can by choosy with ammo, so if the best accuracy possible is desired, the shooter really needs to test several different loads.

I saw a PSA barrel shoot a 2.5 MOA 5 round group with cheap Wolf Gold. That's a respectable group for a budget barrel and ammo.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>56431338
It's the same damn thing as every other AR manufacturer is making. They sell it to customers at wholesale price, the same price they'd give to dealers buying in bulk. That's their business model.

If anything were wrong with the quality it would be in the barrel, and AR barrels are easy to replace. Test the barrel and swap it if you're not getting good accuracy. Protip: it's probably your skill level. Do not buy into this BS that the same model of gun which costs double is double better. It's likely not even 5% better fit/finish. ARs aren't hard to make nor are they expensive to make. They honestly shouldn't cost more than $300. PSA is good about labeling models as "blem" or blemished which means there's something slightly wrong with it, but it's still a usable rifle. This doesn't mean the finish is blemished, it could even be a crookedly drilled hole or a slightly misaligned rivet. At least they label these and some people will take the discounted gun and not care for the imperfection. But for ARs this is rare because they get the parts from other sources & just finish them, get a non-blem one and test the barrel for accuracy or look up accuracy test videos. That's the only thing that can make an AR shit is a bad barrel and from what I know their barrels are fine.

posts.com:
We should debate the /k/est strap opinions. I guess when it comes to roughness there's only the choice between nylon NATO/ZULU straps or typical rubber diving straps found on G-Shocks and others.

I used to be a NATO afficionado. But then I bought my first G-Shock and found out one giant plus: I don't know if it's because of the diameter of my wrist or the fact that I'm a really hairy motherfucker, but:
Watches with rubber bands tend to stay in place (radial speaking) even if I don't tighten the strap too much.
I found this out just a few days ago. I changed the rubber strap of my G-Shock for a NATO strap with adapters. As soon as I did it the watch startet rotating on my wrist to the outside. So when I wanted to take a look at it I had to use the other hand and reposition it.
Even when I tightened the strap real bad it was the same thing.
I then tried out other NATO straps because I thought it was a material-related problem. It wasnt tho.
Also played around with my much heavier Citizen BN0150-10E. Same problem, same solution.
Anyone else here who noticed this?

posts.name: Anonymous

>>56433132
>Would the South have won if the border slave states joined it?

Unironically yes. The border states were considerably more industrialized and had larger populations (almost as importantly, their populations were overwhelmingly free whites, with only 10-20% being slaves). The border states were also very mountainous, meaning that it would have been considerably more difficult for the Union Army to break into the Deep South with the Confederate Army forward deployed into the mountains of Kentucky, Missouri, and West Virginia.

One of the biggest contributions to Union victory was the fact that the average Missourian and Kentuckian opted to stay home rather than take sides.

t. Missouri

>Why didn't they?

They were considerably less enthusiastic about secession in part because being closer to the North meant that abolitionism was somewhat more acceptable, and in part because the average citizen of these states was under no illusion that their farms and homes would be the battlefield if they seceded.

posts.com:
I'm not certain they would've won if the border states and unequivocally supported the South. For at least two of those states its unlikely they would've heavily supported the South.

Some of the states were hardly neutral. West Virginia formed by separating from Virginia due to their disagreement in seceding from the Union. So while they were a 'border state' they were firmly pro-Union and largely supported the Union's war effort.

Kentucky had a more balanced approach but by late 1862 it was mostly pro-Union. After Polk's failed attempt to seize Kentucky for the Confederacy the states Legislature asked the Union army for assistance and from that point on the state while nominally neutral was mostly supportive of the Union war effort. The estimates I've seen of Kentuckians serving in the Union army over the Confederacy was roughly 4 to 1.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>56409001
I couldn't tell you about the 80's as I was too young, but in the 90's there was just as much focus on self-defense, it's just that the meta was handguns. ARs and other modern military style rifles were a thing, but they were a niche like any other whereas now they are sort of the defacto standard. I think there's five main reasons why the AR became as popular as it is today:
1) the Clinton AWB, and laws like it, made people REALLY want what the gov said that they couldn't have. Plenty of people who previously didn't really care one way or the other about ARs suddenly wanted one because this might be their last chance to get one.
2) As the market grew ARs became inexpensive. The fact that they are so modular meant that people could buy one part-by-part as they could afford.
3) They are available in a variety of calibers and configurations which mean they are honestly a very practical suggestion for a variety of applications, from target shooting to hunting to defense.
4) They are honestly very simple to use. Accessible is another way to describe it: Recoil is light, manual of arms is simple, gun is easy to clean, work on, and modify. Ammo is relatively inexpensive compared to other calibers. It is beginner-friendly.
5) It's appearance in media, i.e. games and action movies. Media has always driven people's interest in guns, like boomers going nuts for old Colts because that's what The Lone Ranger, etc, had in their old B&W TV westerns.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I was a kid just starting to get into guns in the mid 80s. Lived the 90s until the end of the ban.

Almost everyone was an old fudd. In the 80s, I’d walk into a gun store and a bunch of fat geriatrics would stare at me with hostility. You would hear unironic “that thar guns no good fur nuthin cept killin people”s. There were no vet bros. Actual Vietnam vets kept quiet and fat men larped as green berets badly. The older people were mostly into deer guns, shotguns, and revolvers. 9mm and .223 were mouseguns and wouldn’t kill a man even though that’s the only thing they were good for. Semiauto anything was unreliable. Also you were obviously a bad shot if you had a gun that held more than six rounds. However, for young guys it was a wonderland. Watching 80s action movies with no assault weapons ban to stop you from owning what you saw in the movies. Young guys would watch an Arnold movie or Lethal Weapon and go out and buy a HK91 and a Beretta 92. The wall had started to come down and ex-Soviet guns were flooding the market. I had an AK and a SKS and dirt cheap x39. Often if you bought a SKS they’d give you a case of x39 for free. Once a fudd literally ran from the range when I brought out my AK because he thought it was illegal. Military surplus, even US guns, were still cheap. M1 carbines for under $200 any time you wanted one. Of course we all had shotguns and .357s too. Even with all the other stuff, shotguns and .357s were best for home defense. No internet. You bought at the local gun store or a gun show if you wanted something harder to get. Most people were more laid back about guns in day to day life, but somehow gun grabbers were on the advance everywhere. I remember sitting on the trunk of a car openly examining a M1 carbine in a McDonalds parking lot.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
94 came and so did the ban. Suddenly those worthless poodle shooters were the hot thing. Everyone was buying them. Almost overnight, fudds became an endangered species. Gun culture became unified around the philosophy of not step back. Paranoia ramped up with Waco after Ruby Ridge. There was a lot of survivalism and militias.

Military surplus was still cheap. The new double stack pistols and self-defense became the new focus and concealed carry laws became widespread. That was followed by an assortment of compacts and subcompacts. Despite the bans, revolvers began to slowly fall out of favor. Ammunition and Chinese guns were still plentiful and cheap even after the import bans.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: 2004 and the ban sunset. I stayed home and watched the Senate debate and finally fail to pass the renewal. I stayed up until midnight of the day of the sunset and instantly converted my guns to no ban configuration at 12:01. I called the gun shop the day after the sunset and they told me there was a truckload of high capacity Glock magazines on the way. Every pistol I had got out fitted with a full complement. The surplus started to dry up through the 00s but this was the era of the AR and vet bro. Fudds disappeared almost entirely and pro gun attitudes hardened even further. Gun forums became a thing and actual information replaced fuddlore. Foreign companies started assembling or importing some of the guns that had been discontinued during the ban. There were choices like never before.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: If you look at my gun collection in the order I got them you can see the distinct eras. What was cheap and available and what was state of the art in each time period from 1985 until 2022 are all represented.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: I grew up in the ban, I remember my dad and I would make it a point to go to gun shows together. He would always buy me some jerky from the jerky guy. I remember I had saved up like 200 bucks once and brought it to the show with me. I think i was 8 or 9, and there was a guy that had a table with CRATES, LITERAL FUCKIN CRATES of mosins and SKSs. My dad was standing there with me and I got my first rifle that wasnt a gift that day. I gave the man 50 dollars for a mosin and he gave me a spam can of ammo "cause a young man shouldnt have a gun without any ammo". I remember my dad explaining to me why we couldnt have full auto rifles and grenade launchers. I remember the gun store my dad and i went to was a pretty comfy little spot. I remember hearing all the fuddlore and my dad would laugh and when we would get in the truck hed tell me those old coots were retarded. They had alot of hunting rifles and shot guns. I also remember the gun ranges were alot different. There was an old WW2 vet at our gun club that showed up twice a year with his garand and his 1911 he took home from the war. The guys were all... different. People talked to each other. And being a kid at the time id see someone shooting a cool gun and want to go see it. If i went over most every time they would let me shoot it, then let my dad shoot it, then it just became guys shooting each others guns and having a great time. Hell i even remember me and my asshole friends riding our bikes all over the damn county with our .22s over our shoulders and little CCI 50 round boxes of ammo jammed in our pockets. It was great. When the ban ended me and my dad both bought ARs. He got a full on A2 clone, i wanted an M4 clone.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>56424928
1990's gun show nostalgia is great. Fudd lore was the rule of the day and a lot of the guys that were into military rifles were survivalist types that also had conversion books and the jolly roger cookbook on those wire shelves for about $5 apiece. I tried every trigger gimmick like the hellfire and the GAT trigger on my Norinco SKS and they were all shit. Dad and I had fun with it though. I'm lucky to have a cool dad that likes fun shit. I got a ban model MAK 90 and shot hundreds of beavers with it after my uncle would blow their dams with Tovex at our farm. The beavers would come back that same night and I'd light them up. There weren't really any good ways to mount lights to AK's back then so dad hose clamped a mag light to it and away I went. The guys at the pawn shop down the road liked me and used to call me when crates of chink 7.62X39 would show up. It smelled like eggs. We have a lot more variety of high quality stuff for better prices these days for sure but those old imports like the Maadis, SKS's, SAR-1's, etc were awesome. Everybody hated the WASR-10 63's when they came out because compared to the others, they were shit. They're still shit but they're functional.

Bill Wilson
Sober N Still Crazy

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Gear was all over the place.
- Kramer was starting to make kick ass horsehide holsters but the waiting list was long
- DeSantis was shitting out copy cat holsters like crazy
- kydex hadn't hit the scene yet
- People still thought shoulder holster was ok
- Ammo was still in the stone age
- red dot sights were just about to show up on rifles with the Aimpoint ML and ML2, would hit the big time with Army adoption of M68 CCO (close combat optic, the Aimpoint)
- pic rail wasn't a thing yet
- keymod and M-LOK didn't exist
- Barrett was still tinkering on his 50BMG rifle
- people thought the Secamp was an ok pocket pistol, if you could find one
- swat vest meta was velcro with snap grid, we are a long way from plate carrier and battle belt
- AR magazines were GI only, Thermold was shit, Lancers were shit, Ramline was shit, all the steel AR mags were shit, nobody made good aftermarket mags for the AR
- Magpul's founder was still in the Rangers, dicking around with a better way to pull magazines out of webgear
- high power rifle matches were still M1 Garand and M1A, the AR15 taking over was still a few years off
- tactical light meta was the Surefire 6P. About 20 minutes of runtime on a set of CR123.
- Surefire desperately trying to push the Surefire 6Z and the "cigar grip"
- Doc Dater and Greg Latka form Gemtech and start plugging away in Boise ID at Gemtech
- NFA items, especially suppressors, were nowhere as mainstream as they are today
- CLEO still had to signoff
- police meta was 870 in the rack, if they were authorized
- police pistol was 3rd or 4th gen S&W on the hip, slowly displaced by Glock brand Glock pistols
- Dillon's Blue Press was worth the subscription (free)
- ditto Shotgun News (paid, unless you knew people)
- Brownell's catalog was like Christmas catalogs used to be
- AR rifle sling meta was the 3-point sling
- you wouldn't try to introduce a new rifle or pistol without getting a couple of Dick Kramer line drawings to show your new toy in "action"

posts.com:
things you'll need to make black powder
potassium nitrate, sulfur, airfloat charcoal preferably of a hardwood
rock tumbler
lead tumbling media
isopropyl alcohol
rubber gloves
kitchen weight scale
a mesh screen of the correct size holes to get proper grain size during corning process

mix the ingredients into the rock tumbler with lead milling media and wet with isopropyl alcohol to prevent ignition

make sure to keep your black powder mix wet with isopropyl alcohol during the entire process drying is only the very last step

run the black powder mix through the screen when it has the consistency of playdough to corn it and let air dry
(I REPEAT AIR DRY ONLY)
some guy tried drying his powder in a pan over a fire and set his porch and himself on fire don't be him

75% nitrate,15% charcoal, 10% sulfur

red gum can be added if you wish but using the method above will give you powder made similarly to how it was made up to the napoleonic wars

>>56348456
Making black powder for your own personal use is legal as long as you don't exceed 50 pounds: https://www.atf.gov/explosives/qa/black-powder-subject-regulation-under-federal-explosives-laws

>Black powder is an explosive material for purposes of federal explosives laws and regulations.
>However, the law exempts from regulation commercially manufactured black powder in quantities not exceeding 50 pounds (as well as percussion caps, safety and pyrotechnic fuses, quills, quick and slow matches, and friction primers) intended to be used solely for sporting, recreational, or cultural purposes in antique firearms as defined in 18 U.S.C. 921(a)(16) or in antique devices exempted from the term "destructive device" in 18 U.S.C. 921(a)(4).
>Regardless, persons engaged in the business of importing, manufacturing, or dealing in black powder in any quantity must have a federal explosives license, and comply with recordkeeping, storage and conduct of business requirements.
>[18 U.S.C. 841(c), 841(d), 845(a)(5); 27 CFR 555.11: definitions of "explosives" and "explosive materials", 555.141(b)]

While legal it's still dangerous, please do not burn down your house.

>>56336361
Black powder isn't a nitrated compound so it doesnt break down into unstable compounds over time like some explosives do. Like that other anon said it can be stored indefinitly.
It's important to keep in mind though that potassium nitrate is very hygroscopic meaning it will pull moisture out of the air making it clump and not work well if not stored air tight.
Don't know if there are any performance graphs of improperly stored black powder but from working a lot with rocket-candy (Sugar and potassium nitrate) I can say that it has a huge effect.

>>56387203
I did a bit of extra digging to find the exact statute and found this
MCL 28.432 (The Janet Kulak Act)
>Inapplicability of MCL 28.422
>(1) Section 2 does not apply to any of the following:
>(h) Purchasing, owning, carrying, possessing, using, or transporting an antique firearm. As used in this subdivision, "antique firearm" means that term as defined in section 231a of the Michigan penal code, 1931 PA 328, MCL 750.231a
Section 2 of 28.422 outlines the states pistol registration system
MCL 750.231a defines antiques as the following
>(i) A firearm not designed or redesigned for using rimfire or conventional center fire ignition with fixed ammunition and manufactured in or before 1898, including a matchlock, flintlock, percussion cap, or similar type of ignition system or replica of such a firearm, whether actually manufactured before or after 1898
So tl;dr you havent needed to get a purchase permit for a BP revolver unless you stick a conversion cylinder in it since 2004 when MCL 28.432 passed

i asked this already but couldnt follow up on the thread because irl, but:
china and russia messed around with basically captive piston ammunition. basically the bullet is pushed out of the case with a piston, that then seals the case, trapping the gas inside the case. they did it to make silenced revolvers and pistols that didnt need suppressors to fire quietly.
so, couldnt you do this with blackpowder? the case would trap the fouling, contain the smoke it produces, and be pretty quiet compared to regular guns.

so, while it would be hard and expensive to make the ammo itself, if you could make this ammo, couldnt you basically make a internally suppressed machine gun that requires no registration, breaks no laws, and isnt even considered a firearm but a blackpowder weapon, meaning even felons could own it?

>>56431690
Nagorno-Karabakh in 2020 is definitely what changed my mind about Russian equipment and doctrine in general. a lot of Armenian armor just got fucked up by drones and also by Spike ATGMs being used by the Azeris. and even before the Azeris were able to take control of Shusha and most of Karabakh's lowlands, the Armenians used pretty basic Russian/Soviet ATGMs to stave off (mostly) Russian-made APCs and tanks used in the initial Azeri push (I believe most of the Azeri soldiers in this first phase were actually Syrian jihadi mercenaries, just as a note). considering both the Azeris and Armenians get pretty modern Russian-made stuff, it seemed like the Russians really hadn't come up with decent countermeasures against ATGMs like the Israelis and Americans have.

the biggest issue in this conflict though was just how exposed Russian IADSs were to SEAD practices. Azeris using rigged up An-2 drones to bait out SAM networks, then having Harops, Bayraktars, and Su-25s armed with PGMs performing NATO-style high-altitude SEAD missions really badly wounded Armenia's SAM inventory. the Russians did allegedly deploy their Krasukha-4 jammer to counter the drones, but the reports made it difficult to assess its efficacy, and in general it seems the Russians weren't willing to give more of them to their allies and probably didn't have many themselves to use effectively in an EW and C-UAS role.

The biggest takeaway about all of this isn't that the most advanced Russian tanks are dogshit garbage, it's that

and b) it doesn't matter how good the T-90 is on a 1 to 1 basis with comparable modern tanks if you lose a shit ton of them to ATGMs and poor (application of) doctrine, and you're forced to roll out reserves of T-64s and other outdated Soviet tanks.

They don't have the numbers to deploy them, they're losing too many because of poor planning, strategy, and tactics, and they haven't nearly set up the logistical backing necessary to prevent perfectly good tanks from being abandoned due to lack of fuel or easily repairable damage/mobility losses.

Ok /k/, so you are transported into a comic strip world. In this world you are in a large densely populated city. The city gets attacked on a regular basis by various threats in a monster of the week format.

You may choose any weapon to use in this defense. This includes anything from small arms like a pair of 1911s, up to fighter jets like the Harrier, or tanks like the M1 Abrams. The only caveat is that it must exist in real life.

Also, threats scale based on the relative strength of your weapon. So if you pick a machinegun expect body snatchers, gangsters, and frankesntein monsters; pick a tank and expect mad scientists with death rays, and kind kong; plane? ufos and pterodactyls; and if you pick something massive like a battleship then expect godzilla to show up.

What do you pick? What do you call yourself?
